review: The apartment has a serious mould and damp issue that runs deeply throughout the whole place. The mould ruined a majority of my furniture and personal possession including a sofa, drawers, a bookshelf and countless bags, shoes belts not to mention my partners amp he had since he was 15. We also experienced health issues, from irritated eyes to rashes and for myself my asthma became unmanageable from breathing in the mould particles. The apartment needs serious work before it can be rented out again and I would hope that this happens so no one else experiences this.

Love living in public housing. Public Housing should be much more widespread. 1970s cream brick. 3 spacious bedrooms, Cozy kitchen/diner, living room with space to move, and bathroom/laundry combo. Wood floorboards throughout. Front and backyards. Design is practical but nice. Would definitely recommend South Australian Housing Trust!

Property is fine, owners do respond to maintenance requests. Property is not double glazed as advertised, open plan means heating costs you a fortune. Owners live in the back property and will come over without notice if the real estate agent doesn't respond to them fast enough. They also do their own repairs and have people enter the property who aren't actually doing the repairs.

It rains in the bedroom and the laundry when it rains outside. Health really suffered. Always incredibly damp. The mould is rampant. Landlord never did anything about it. The foundations are rotting and there are several windows which have holes at the edge because of the rot. There is moss growing inside.

The house was a wreck and the owner wants to do nothing to fix it as they want to build apartments.  The wooden stumps are rotten and the house has drops of up to 30cm of the floor level in some corners. The house is so twisted that some windows have cracked. There are holes in walls where previous tenants have opened doors too hard and the handle has gone though the wall. 
There is a derelict bungalow in the back yard that is surrounded with old building materials and things like old hot water services. Currently is only good for the local rat population to breed in.  REA was indifferent to all of this and refused to do anything to resolve the issues as there would always be someone else who will put up with it if I didn't

It's actually really fantastic for what it is. I hoped to live there for many years with my cats, and the landlords seemed nice. However one point has to be taken off for the shit real estate who turns tenants and landlords against each other, and are generally cunts in a lot of ways. Another point has to be taken off for the toilet plumbing needing a rectification order, which unfortunately I can't pursue for the next tenant's sake now that my lease has been terminated. The pipes are collapsed, and if they keep having to blast it or drain snake it, eventually it will completely collapse and claim the plumber's expensive equipment, and suddenly render the property uninhabitable until rectified.

Everything constantly breaks, the landlord gets his friend to fix anything, and his friend does a shoddy job every time. The landlord also works FIFO month on month off and tells the real estate to wait to do anything until he gets home. There are gaps in between the floor and walls, I made them fill some with sellys no more gaps, but there's still more.

The place had a mould and a German cockroach infestation. There is also only three power points in the entire rental and you would have constant blackouts. The place was also a half house, and you couldn't access your switchboard on the patio on 1/21 Morgan St to turn on the electricity as the real estate said it was a breach of their privacy. Water tasted badly so I had to buy bottled water while living here.

Black mold present, bad plumbing outside and backyard would flood every time it would rain, bad electrical wiring outside where it would flood. Bungalow had roof water damage but landlord wouldn't pay to fix, room has a funky smell. Repeated gas leaks from oven inside and outside bungalow, took them two weeks to fix the bungalow gas leak which my roommate was staying in. Fence kept falling down and people could just come into our backyard, the 'fix' was a couple screws. Advertises a 'car spot' but the gate is heavy and hard to move, street parking on this corner is guaranteed to be your car written off. Our front fence got crashed into three times in a 1 year lease. Agency was really unhelpful with any fix and had told another tenant that they wouldn't be a good reference for me as I had requested things to be fixed. One working stove burner for almost 6 months and agency kept blaming covid.
During our tenancy, thousands upon thousands of litres of water spilled under the house from a burst water main.. it's an old house go figure. Mold already present. I would not rent this house.
No bedroom window that opens, zero ventilation and simply inhabitable in summer (the highway fumes are an added bonus when the balcony door opens)

Actual plants would grow up from the middle of the house (not by the window, but from the floor in the middle of the house where there was a cupboard), SO much mould. A bug problem because of holes in the wall leading to the outside. Reported problems, no fix.

Very dark, dank, cold house. Mould growing in cornices, on front door and there was clearly mould damage in 3rd bedroom from before we moved in that has been painted over. Not built for living in mind. Internet port is miles away from any power point so you have to run an extension cord from behind the fridge. There is space for a front loader washing machine only beneath the benchtops, but nowhere to plug it in so you have to run it over the top of the bench. Very steep driveway and it is challenging to get a car in the garage but council is cracking down on parking at the top of the driveway. There is no street parking as its all no stopping signs on this side of the road. There have been consistent mouse problems (evident even in the imprint of one in the concrete before it even dried in the garage) and you can't use the laundry sink without the washer plugged in because it overflows into the cupboard. Water pressure is awful and the water is barely more than lukewarm. Real estate treat you like a product they are selling to the owners and don't care about you as a person. We were there for 2 years and they raised the rent every 6 months, despite there being several properties in the area that are significantly below what they are asking for. (We just moved into a property that is slightly bigger in a more central area for $70 a week less.)
Good rental and pretty reasonable agency.

It was full of mould and the landlord & real estate FINALLY sent out a mould doctor, but it came back. Was constantly a low level of sick in the time I lived there. Oven didn't work the entire time I lived there, there was no heating and I fought for a year to get a proper lock on my front door.

Agency was pretty good at contacting us. Fixed most issues when needed. When the air con was leaking in summer it was fixed quickly. We got the bond back and workers were polite. We did get nervous of reporting issues as the rental crisis worsened. By the time we moved out there were unresolved electrical issues that went somewhat ignored. They only upped our rent by 131 a month but when we decided to move out they dramatically raised the rent for the next person. A nice and quiet area to live but the property itself was not worth more than the 2k a month we paid it rent for it. The third bedroom was so small and unusable as a bedroom.

Mould. Down hallway, lounge and particularly in these two sunrooms at front of flat (where the mould was past description, across roof, windows, walls). I was there for years and one day (I think it was around 2020) I reported this mould, asking for it to be cleaned and got an eviction notice delivered in the letterbox two hours after my email. Mould was at levels beyond hazardous.

Left with no working oven, no working bathroom sink for months and months with no repairs. Guttering had major issues which eventually led to mould, literally would rain inside the living room next to front door. The corners the guttering/roof all rotted off,  Was told by agent that the landlord can't afford repairs during covid. Agent implied we should just wash our faces in the kitchen sink. 

Kitchen is handmade poorly, draws are awkward sizes that have 20 layers of paint on and don't close properly, pantry has sticking out nails to hang stuff on, again very DIY and shoddy. 

Half the windows don't open, none of the interior doors seem to close. Floorboards have holes and are paper thin in many areas, had a letter once sent to the house which was meant to go to the landlord saying the house needs to be investigated for termites. 

Bathroom has rotten lino and is mold prone, sink and toilet are super old and barely worked when did. 

Aircon was replaced in the bedroom early on in our tenancy but would just freeze up and never work. 

Have been told by many electricians that the wiring in this house needs upgrading, asked many times about this and nothing ever happened.  

Also side note to anyone considering this dump of a home, the house next door has a lot of people around at all hours of the night and have stolen shoes / belongings off the back deck and under the house serveral times. 

Was paying $375 from 2018-2021. Don't let them get away with hiking the rent up. even if basic repairs do get made this is just not a property worth paying for unless serious renovations are done. Hopefully the house gets sold to an owner who cares one day.

Look, I loved this shitty little house, but between the tap constantly falling off the kitchen sink, tiles randomly falling off & pieces of the ceiling falling onto my head while in the bath, I can't recommend it. Also, the landlord lived next door & constantly came over without warning, he pulled out plants he gave us permission to plant & no one gave us any warning the the entire fence was coming down as the apartments being built next door needed to move it. We had dust & debris on our washing & an unsafe front yard full of tradie shit. When we complained to the real estate, they said a new fence would go up eventually. There was constantly strange people in our yard, which made me feel very unsafe.
An old Queenslander that is literally falling apart. Nothing works in the kitchen. The bathroom leaks under the floor. The windows are cracked or missing.

There were cracks in the grout in the shower floor which meant water was going under the bathroom floor and coming out in different places. Our house referred to our bathroom as “the swamp”. The oven would randomly switch off.

This is the best rental I've ever had. The landlords genuinely care & are great people. They've been more proactive than the agency! They basically rebuilt our shower after we told them in person that the tiles were “squishy” & were grateful we told them - the agency hadn't passed the info on. They've also raised rent by only $20 in the past two years. I'm so glad we found this home amongst all the horrors out there.

Paid $680/week for a unit with no room for a dining table and no outdoor area, with rising damp, fly infestation, mould riddled throughout. Agency provided us with one dehumidifier for a 2 bed unit after complaining multiple times about mould over 2 years. They sprayed the mould once and never followed up. No cross ventilation or fan in bathroom/laundry. Pillows would feel wet to touch due to the moisture and we plowed through damprid. Anything leather would be covered in mould, even when in open hallway and skirting boards all covered. Landlord/agency also initially refused to replace mouldy/water damaged bathroom sink cupboard after a pipe burst and when they did, they only replaced the doors, not the mouldy shelving inside. Eventually moved out after 2 years, threw away almost everything we had there and immediately felt better, no more sore throats or lethargy, and the cats actually started the play and run around again. They rented it out after us for $780. 0/10 do not rent.

The house is a 4 bedroom 1.5 bathroom - but it's on tank water, has a septic tank, and is on a 4 acre block for which the rental agreement required us to keep the lawns maintained. We spent $200 a month on filling the water tank because when we first moved in the gutters weren't connected to the tank, so it wasn't collecting any rain water. The week we moved in the ceiling in the dining room leaked and split open, it took almost 10 months for them to send a repair man out to fix it - meanwhile we were paying $700 in rent.

Everything that the agency advertised to be in 'working order' is broken. Heater is leaking gas - just told “don't use it”, other heater is ducted and spitting out bits of the foil insulation whenever turned on, heater panel also fell off the wall and has live wires dangling. Garage door fell off the hinges with my car inside the garage- car was trapped in garage for over a week as door could not open. Garage now has no door on it for time being as owners cannot afford to replace it. Tiles in bathroom literally sticky taped on with black mould growing under sticky tape. Dishwasher has an error code that indicates water is getting in to electrical panel- refusing to service or replace it. No working exhaust fans. Real estate agency is clearly one that manages Chinese owned investment properties- incredibly unprofessional. When I ask for something to be fixed their response is landlord cannot afford it - “perhaps you would prefer to just not renew your lease at the end of the period if you're unhappy with the state of the property.” Paying wayyyyy above market value.

We moved in at the start of the pandemic, was unemployed & desperate for a rental. When we first moved in all the walls were covered in cigarette smoke. The walls were yellow and sticky to touch with paint peeling on the walls and multiple patch jobs with no paint over the top. There was black areas on the bathroom ceiling, between my bad eyesight, naivety & desperation for a roof over our heads. We signed the lease.
The shower, the laundry sink and the kitchen all leaked. The kitchen sink leaked into the cupboards. The toilet leaked. The carpet was so old that you could see the flooring underneath (cunts still expected carpet cleaning at the end of the tenancy) and I stabbed myself on the exposed nails numerous times. The kitchen bench was covered in knife marks. The front door was completely water damaged and was just a decoration.  The blinds were so broken you could see completely through them and had no privacy anywhere, including the bedroom. They even charged previous tenant for blinds, didn't get replaced. The mould started growing back 2 weeks after we moved in. The exhaust fan didn't work. The bathroom turned into a sauna after a shower. No fly screen on window, so was difficult keeping it open. An unbelievable amount of condensation on the window, over a 200ml per day. Window was so water damaged that the wood was falling apart around it. Windows  leaked when raining. Could feel a breeze when 1m away from all windows. Spent many weekends trying to contain and clean the mould. After 18 months LL finally 'fixed' it. He hired mould men, absolutely horrible company that just sprayed a solution, wiped the walls and called it a day. The mould returned after a month. Rent April $220 now $310 listed recently. 1 bed very small unit. The mould was through the whole block of units.

I reviewed the agency separately, they engaged in several questionable or illegal actions while we rented through them. This review is for the landlord and his one-of-ten investment properties specifically. He was rude to us, to trades fixing his property, and to his property managers on several occasions. He would carry out repairs himself, or if they required "licensed" repairs, always seemed to have a "licensed" buddy who he'd come around with and supervise. He would turn up unannounced or when we had declined him access (because he'd give 0-2 hours notice on average that he wanted to come around). We breached him on quiet enjoyment grounds for this and it did continue to happen. The house, while quite a nice house of itself, was terribly maintained. Mice and rats came in through unsealed plumbing in the kitchen. The gutters were filthy when we moved in (a previous resident had been throwing toilet rolls out the upstairs ensuite window for some reason, these were among many leaves, weeds and dirt in the gutters) and were literally never cleaned even though we flagged this at every inspection. A leak in one of the gutters turned out to have been an internal pipe that had been leaking into a wall upstairs then onto a roof for an extended time. That pipe did eventually burst catastrophically, caving in the master bedroom ceiling and leaving that room uninhabitable for nearly 3 months while we waited for repairs. We were offered no compensation nor any rent relief for this despite requesting it. Instead we were offered/told that our rent would increase at the next lease cycle. We vacated after all this, despite the rent crisis and our own circumstances meaning this was quite difficult physically to achieve, but we literally preferred to be homeless and couch surf rather than pay this landlord a single cent more than we already had. Avoid.

The landlord of this property is absolutely the worst. We moved in to discover that the air conditioning wasn't working, the toilet seat had fallen off, the windows didn't open and a gas heater had fallen off the wall. Upon reporting this to the agent, the agent said the landlord wanted to come and inspect these issues. The landlord then spent 90 minutes trying to claim that we as the tenants were responsible for all these things. It took relentless emails, and phone calls for three months and a ultimately a VCAT hearing to get these things fixed. Later on during our tenancy our hot water started to sporadically stop working. On three seperate occasions a plumber was sent out and each time, the plumber (different plumbers each time) said that the hot water service was unfixable and needed replacing. The landlord ignored this advice and told them to do a Band-Aid fix. This culminated in me coming home from work one day to discover that the the hot water service had ruptured and there was water gushing out which filled the room the unit was in and also leaked through the floor into the room below. It took over a week and another VCAT hearing to get the unit replaced. Two weeks after winning that case through VCAT we were given notice to vacate at the end of our lease. After this the roller door in the back yard collapsed on my head (luckily I was wearing a helmet at the time). The tradie they sent out to repair it said it needed replacing. The landlord ignored that advice and it collapsed again. This time around the landlord himself came out to attempt a repair.

House was spacious and generally in good order, but a few things to be wary of with the landlord/realestate. 

1. The owner will just drop in when it pleases them to raid your garden for plants to use at their other rental properties. Additionally, the owner's family lives over the road. I was accused of subletting and threatened with legal action because I bought a new car that wasn't recognised. Makes you feel like you're under surveillance. 

2. Gas is a bit dodgy. Gas leak was reported to atco and they turned the gas off as it was unsafe. Real estate and landlords argued with atco, gas stayed off for days. Gas fitter they got to replace pipes created a mess and complained the whole time. Didn't think to ask for certification at the time 

3. House is nice but we did get kicked out for a remodel so not sure how it is today, but it was hot in the summer freezing in the winter!

The landlord built it and the stairs were so thin I fell down and got a head injury from then and when I told the real estate they said “oh they're a bit tricky aren't they” but said it's all to code. It was a furnished house even with a huge sweat stain on the mattress. When I moved the bed it fell apart cause it was held together with glue. The furnished washing machine would flood the house. It was concrete floors and brick walls so was 10 degrees in winter but the furnished heater would short circuit the electrical. It came with a furnished tv that still had an antenna. It was a loft house so as a 5ft person, I still could only use half of the upstairs without hitting my head. Because I didnt want to sleep on the stained mattress I had to pay to store the owners shit in a storage unit and I said to the property manager that everybody else who rents it will do the same and she says no we have a lot of furnished houses and that I'm the first to do it. It was furnished even to the point of having coffee and tea canisters. When I moved in and tried to get power and internet set up, the providers couldn't figure out the address and the real estate never got back to me about what the actual address was. I broke the lease early after I got a concussion and the real estate charged me a cleaning fee for dirt behind a bathroom cabinet, that no one can reach, that the property manager would have had to get on her hands and knees to take a photo of

Black mould in all the rooms for 2 years and nothing done about it. Shit pouring out of the sewage pipes and nothing done about it. Tree falling onto shed with all my work tools and told I have to replace the shed if I want one. Broke the lease and moved out.

This house is terrible. It's quite old and has cracks everywhere in the walls exposing the outside. Often we would have plants growing through the walls everywhere. Huge mice and mould issues that never got fixed. Landlord likes to do shotty repairs himself rather than pay a professional. Landlord lives overseas most of the time too. DO NOT RENT HERE

Kitchen cupboards falling apart, Lino peeling. Patchwork floorboards with segments cracking, large concrete patch. Dated bathroom with plumbing issues. Bad electric wiring. Dated wardrobe. Window sashes break frequently.

Cupboards/drawers/built ins don't really work, doors/drawers fall out/off. Landlord refused to fix. Pest problems though eventually had it sprayed after 3 months and a form 10. Minor mould issues. Landlord not willing to repair things or perform routine maintenance.

Lived here for 7 months. The house was mouldy in every room, lost countless valuable items including a $2k bed frame and mattress. Only one heater in the whole property and it was constantly breaking. Grass and mushrooms growing out of the floorboards too. Agency did nothing to remedy any of these issues and when we broke lease they tried to take our bond. We refused as we broke lease rightfully so. This house is falling apart and is a massive health hazard.

To preface, the property is $900 a week for a 3 bed 1 bath, with one of the beds being 2mx2.5m. The kitchen was smaller and the toilet/shower was barely big enough to move around in. The moment we started the lease we noted a few issues, the second door was having issues opening and shutting, the oven only produced smoke amd for the entire tenancy that was nevwr fixed. The landlord repeatedly visited the outside always claiming he was "checking the gutters", we were brilliant tenants, even fixing stuff that was not ours to fix. Finally, the back door broke, to the point it wouldnt open unless you had 1 foot pushed on the door frame as kt was off its hinges. This was reported and reminded for 14 months, nothing happened, the LL+RA had an inspection during this time and couldn't inspect the back yard due to this. During this period despite not fixing the obvious fire risk they instead raised the rent by $100 a week.

I absolutely loved this house and I genuinely wish the agency had listened and remedied our issues. I would have stayed there for a very long time. 

This property was built by the old couple that lived in it their whole life and you could tell it wasn't built by professionals. Leaks in the plumbing, blocked plumbing constantly. Mould in bathroom, shed roof caving in, wall paper in really bad state, mould in bathroom & upstairs “bedroom”, I put bedroom in quotation marks because they advertise it as a 5 bedroom house but the 2 rooms upstairs are so small you can't even fit a bed in them, only one heater and when it broke it took the realestate MONTHS (during winter) to do anything and then it broke again. It was sold when we were living in it and the weekly inspections were really draining we decided to finish up when our lease was over and the realestate almost begged us to stay.. saying that we made this “house a home”. It was condescending to say the least. All they had to do was take our concerns seriously and fix a few issues and we would of been there for many more years. 

Now to the good things the HOUSE IS STUNNING! It is so quirky and the design of it fit our aesthetic. The garden is what dreams are made of and we absolutely loved sitting out there in summer. I truly miss a lot of things about this house. 

If you take a look at it on realestate you can still see the photos they took with our stuff in it :) Twas beautiful

Small, but solid. Landlord actually cares about his tenants. He actually pushes back on the real estate agents when they ask him to raise rent. I was there 9 years and it only went up a total of $15/week.

Thick brick walls do a good job of keeping heat in during winter, and keeping heat out in summer. This also means heat lingers once it does get in. Invest in a good fan. You'll need it during heatwaves.
No fan in bathroom, will cause mold. Keep window open during showers, and clean ceilings regularly before it gets out of control.
Street facing, can be a little bit loud in living area. But it's a relatively quite street, and bedroom is not on street.
Walls thick, but bedroom shares wall with neighbours bedroom. You'll sometimes hear them, but not too bad.
Break ins are a problem in area, which you might hear about. But they are opportunistic. This is a top floor apartment, and off street parking is behind lock up gate. I had no issues in 9 years here.

Perfect for single occupants, but probably a bit too small for a couple.

My best mate, my sister and myself lived here from 2017-2019. Our landlord was abusive and intrusive. She would threaten to kick us out if rent was not in her account by the afternoon of due date. She would constantly come over unannounced and tell us how to garden etc. She would send us abusive emails calling us names, and 'bad tenants' if we ever asked for repairs. She often would tell us that we were at fault for any problems with the house. She would give less then 24 hours notice to enter the house and would then walk around telling us everything is in 'disarray' 

The boundary fence between our house and the neighbors was a rotten heap that gradually fell over. About a year into our rental, the fence was removed completely so that we shared a backyard with our neighbor. She she then tried to raise the rent during this time. 

The kicker came in 2019 when a pipe under the bathroom basin burst late one night causing water to flood the bathroom and out into the carpeted hallway. It was 11pm at night, so we called an emergency plumber. The plumber closed off the pipe and said that the copper piping was old and had burst. When we emailed the landlord she became very angry and accused us of malicious damage. She then sent us an eviction notice, giving us 14 days to move out- claiming malicious damage, but also claiming that the landlord was going to move in 🤦🏻‍♀️. With the help and advice from Tenants Victoria, we managed to change the eviction notice to a month and found a new rental fairly quickly. After moving out, the landlord continued to accuse us of damage and tried to withhold our bond, but was unsuccessful. All of us  regret not taking this further, but we were so ignorant and young and really tired of the ongoing verbal and mental abuse. 

Since moving out we have been contacted by new tenants who have had the same experience.

It flooded when I lived there in 2019, the design of the buildings/rear area and the substandard drainage meant that a heavy rain would back up rapidly, which would soon start rushing in through the only exit at the rear of the building (at the lowest point of the whole property) and flood into the lower floor rooms. Easily a few hundred litres came though and emptied through floorboards on the other end of the lower floor.

We had just moved in, so many boxes were soaked. Most furniture was impossible to take up the incredibly narrow stairs, so it was also damaged. It took over a week of constant fan/dehumidifier use to dry the rooms back out while having everything that could not go upstairs on milk crates, being moved around constantly as there was zero usable storage.

After being supplied with sandbags from the local SES, the flooding happened another 7 times before our lease ended, but because of the stack of sandbags we had placed in front of the door (And had to overstep every day) as well as strategic points outside, we prevented it from getting inside since.

A neighbour said it has happened a few times, once being so bad it rushed from the house into his adjoining store.

The owner knew this was a problem.

Upon leaving, the owner tried stinging us for 'paint missing on staircase' (It was so poorly applied it would come off on your hand), but I managed to get full bond returned after blowing up about the flooding they already were very aware of.

When I rented there 4 years ago, it was $475pw, it has recently been leased at $750pw, while still being advertised as "3 Bedroom" (It is not) while one of the upstairs rooms is uninhabitable in summer months...

I could go on...

Any damaged items (doors, carpet, appliances) removed rather than replaced whenever raised with real estate. Rising mold in all rooms, no heating, disconnected phone line.Landlord frequently visited without notice, forced to go to tribunal to recover bond. ( I recovered the bond in full)

When we moved in, the back fence had been down for over a year, there was mould in the bathroom, we had a leaky kitchen tap for 3 months, there was a significant amount of rubbish along the back fence including dangerous and unmaintained gas canisters, the manual garage door broke trapping my car inside (which we had to hoist up ourselves to drive the car out because the landlord complained about cost!), there was a major roof leak across the entire back room of the house that was reported in May and wasn't fixed until after the VCAT hearing and a mould issue appeared after the fix, which had not been dealt with at the time of leaving. In the first month of our lease, a handyman was sent out to inspect all the issues and recommendations were made that would have avoided the roof leak, but the landlord declined and refused to maintain the house appropriately. A large branch of the tree out the front took down the powerlines of next door, and there had been not maintenance on this tree since we moved in, despite council letters about how the tree hung over the powerlines of the house and others which were sent on. The real estate agent we signed with initially fired the landlord as clients because of how unreasonable they were and LJ Hooker replaced them just before we left. The landlord is the problem here. 

At the VCAT hearing, the landlord, unrepresented by an estate agent at this time, showed up late (approx. 20 minutes into the hearing) and proceeded to yell at the VCAT member about how terrible we clearly were and how the broken garage door was clearly our fault, despite a clear presence of rust damage that we could not have caused in the 9 months we were there. He spoke to the member so rudely she had to tell him that he was making the case worse for himself and that he needed to remain quiet. The landlord continued to drag his feet on the repairs but reluctantly completed most of them before we left.

White painted: Toilet cover and vat, faulty electric water heater running all day making bills expensive. Bathroom so prone to mould that you have to leave the windows open 24/7 and a fan running. Mould on the bedroom ceiling. Black carpet full of stains. Painted light switches and plugs. 1300$ month for one bedroom
They painted over mould in every room. There are so many little problems that weren't obvious until after we moved in. Whole building is unsafe. To top it all off, the door is asbestos.

This house is beautiful BUT the landlord was unresponsive with repairs and greedy with returning the bond. After being long term tenants we were evicted during the Moratorium on evictions during the pandemic in 2021. The landlord needed to temporarily move back in to the property while their other property was being renovated. We could have taken them to VCAT over this but we opted to go down the path of least resistance and move out. During the tenancy repairs were frequently ignored, e.g. the dishwasher was broken for 6 months and when I finally escalated it to a formal complaint with the agency, the landlord tried to guilt trip me over it. We also couldn't lock our front or back door and the landlord claimed it was because the 'house shifted' and it would shift back when the weather changed. But we literally couldn't lock the property for months. The property had been a rental for 9 years and in the end they wanted to keep our bond over things that were wear and tear - they also claimed we must have changed the locks because their keys didn't work and so they wanted us to pay for that too - we had to remind them that they told us the 'house shifted' in some seasons and we'd certainly never changed them, but they insisted we pay for replacement locks lol. We countered by saying we wanted a portion of rent returned to us from the 6 months we'd not had a functional dishwasher and that we were happy to go VCAT. With the threat of VCAT the landlord eventually backed down and our bond was returned but it was such a stressful, protracted process to get our bond back for a property we'd really cared for and were unceremoniously evicted from. The agency always defaulted to the landlord's position - if they'd been more firm with the landlord about their legal responsibilities to tenants, a lot of the tedious back and forth could have been avoided.

Mould problems. No internet for two months. Landlord allowed drug addicted nephew to live in a vacant room. Things escalated and police got him out. Him and girlfriend came back that night and made threats. No fans in kitchen. Cockroach infestation.

Leaking roof that wasn't fixed for a year and half, big bubble in the ceiling. Light fixtures near water damaged roof that electricians told us not to use. One hub on stove didn't work the entire time. Oven didn't work the entire time. No insulation, house got to 10 degrees most of the winter. Mould in the bathroom and water leaking behind the tiles in the bathroom. Windows that were cracked, a lot of the windows didn't open. Very poor heating and air conditioning. Uneven floors and doors that didn't close, had to get family to come fix doors so we could shut them. Real estate agent very slow to respond. Raised the rent when they hadn't fixed a majority of issues.

Positives; seperate toilet to bathroom and good size living spaces.

I attended an inspection of this unit and was shocked at the misrepresentation presented by the photos compared to the condition of the place. 

Duct tape held together the screen door, the carpet was different heights in different areas and the bathroom shower looks like it hadn't been cleaned for a long time. 

Soap buildup on the soap holder and the pink mould growing all over the shower tiles. 

The bathroom has been renovated which means it must have been truely awful and disgusting previously, I cannot believe the owner is going to charge someone to move in and clean their house. 

Yuck

Black mould throughout the property, especially in the bathroom. Was told this was my fault and nothing could be done to help me. Not renovated for quite some time so countertops are perpetually grimy no matter how much you clean, balcony does not drain properly, shared paid laundry facilities are often unhygienic and often not working, was charged for 2 end of lease cleans due to issues which were present at beginning of lease and documented and reported, however still lost most of the bond. Entire apartment gets damp after having a shower due to complete lack of ventilation. Apartment came furnished however furnishings had cigarette burns and mould and tears. When I asked if the furnishing could be removed, I had to wait months for approval and was then reprimanded when I vacated, because the worst of the furnishings were missing. I had written confirmation from the landlord that I could remove these items of furniture so I did not understand the further conflict. Also had my lease threatened due to “noise complaints” when I had not been living at the apartment for over two months (but was still paying rent because I wasn't allowed to break lease). Poorly managed property when I lived there, hopefully it has improved in the last year.  Would be perfectly fine with some very affordable renovations. Otherwise, unit is quite safe and has a beautiful view of the park. Was pet friendly which was the main reason I moved in.

This apartment is truly shit. When we arrived it was already mouldy and we suspect it already has a carpet moth problem. It took 12 months and 11 emails for the rental agency to finally remove the mould (during which they didn't tell us we'd have the cladding removed - 6 months of construction from 8-5pm while in lockdown), which took three goes because of insufficient removal, and by then the mould had already caused thousands of dollars in damage to our personal property. There is also a post which has been built in the living room which has a 3cm gap between the glass and the post, where mould thrived.  

No matter what we did, we couldn't keep the mould away. We opened windows, opened doors, and still every morning in winter we'd get up and the glass was covered in condensation. The exhaust fan in the kitchens and bathroom were also virtually non existent. When we left (after months of carpet moths that we couldn't get on top of), we noticed ghosting on the wall, presumably the result of mould or moisture against the back wall - you shouldn't be able to see the frame of the apartment from the inside!  It was clearly a cheap build. We were also told the front door wasn't fire safe, nor was the balcony. The windows also look straight into your neighbours homes, so there's virtually no privacy. 

We were paying $400 a week. When we left it was readvertised for $600.

House is freezing in winter and boiling in summer. No working air con or heater for the whole time we lived there. Noise from main road out front and neighbor is significant. Shower had no screen door so bathroom flooded regularly. When it rained water would leak through walls and down lights - would regularly submit maintainence requests, approved tradies would come out to provide a quote which would then go nowhere and cycle continued for close to a decade.

Landlord with extreme disregard for tenancy agreement.
Landlord and landlord's parents turning up and entering the property without notice.
Evicting tenants based on the tenants providing housing for others during cataclysmic natural disaster.
Plenty more awful stuff just avoid this place and landlord like a plague.
Absolutely abhorent.

This was my husband and I's first apartment together and suffice to say it was a COOKED  experience. 

The apartment itself is a basic, mediocre-made newer apartment. Issues with the build included:
- Window condensation amassing
- Drains randomly clogging
- Shower door seal not attached properly and peeling off
- When you would open doors they'd open into other walls or doors
- Front door would deadlock and couldn't be unlocked. We first moved in none of the doors inside would lock properly unless you manually deadlocked them from the inside. Everyone in the building complained and it was never resolved.
- The common space front door to the building would constantly have to be left open due to deadlocking incorrectly. 
- it was also zoned differently with the council than with the real estate agency. so god forbid you would get any mail delivered. it had two addresses.

The other issues came about from an absolutely buckwild weirdo of a landlord/property investor and the actions of the real estate.
- In 2016 the building was broken into. Everyone's storage cages were slashed open and partially destroyed with everyone losing stuff. The real estate refused to engage with police officers (despite officers asking and needing this for multiple reasons). Our neighbor didn't have her slashed storage cage fixed for 4 months after the break-in and had to used MDF board and a 'decoy' suitcase to block the damaged area. I randomly got a text from the property manager 12 months after the break-in asking for the cops details when she finally decided to respond to their messages.
- After living at the property for 2 years, the dishwasher broke and was flooding. After sending out a plumber (who didn't flush a shit the took in our toilet) this issue still persisted. It was deduced that the issue was a faulty pipe install that had given up the ghost after a period of time. After 4 months of back and forth on getting it fixed, the Landlord visited with the new property manager and gave me a packet of dishwashing tablets because 'modern women like yourself don't know how to do the dishes properly and thats why it's broken'. I explained that i was related to plumbers and that the issue had been deduced to be a faulty pipe. The landlord left  and sent out another plumber when we vacated the property to have it fixed and re-listed.
- The property investor/owner of most the apartments (including ours) had a son with a giant luxury jeep who was working nearby. he would give the son access to our storage units and private garage so he could park his car wherever he wanted. Several times he would park his monster of a jeep in peoples parking spots, which were operated by a elevator system which ended up damaging the carpark system and damaging car spaces. Several times the son also parked his car in front of everyone's cars pots and would leave for hours. We would all not have access to our cars during this time because of this.
- That same son would also carry out random maintenance on the building or just hang out in the garage from time to time. One day he built a private shed over the guest and disabled cars pots in the building and didn't tell the real estate agent who found out during an inspection. We were all told to 'just ignore him, he's built a little house'
- When we vacated the property, we were at first refused our bond returned because 'the landlord wants the apartment in perfect condition as it was a brand new apartment'. We had been told we were ideal tenants during our stay and the place was cleaned from head to toe. We later found out, after many phone calls and contacting the renters union, that he wanted the 'streak marks on the mirrored backsplash gone'. these were from windex we had used to clean it. He also didn't want to return our bond because the balcony 'had puddles on it and the sliding glass door had water droplets on it'. It had rained the day we handed the keys back. We did get our bond back when we threatened VCAT. But the real estate agency had made a series of intimidating phone calls during that week and wanted me to skip work to talk to them, they kept insisting that it was a legal requirement to 'hire their cleaners' when that wasn't true. None of these people were our property manager.

I have never been happier to be out of an apartment.

Since vacating and being out for several years, we found out from small business owners in Murrumbeena that one night someone had firebombed the apartment building during the covid lockdowns. Since looking the property up since then details have been scarce.

Within the first few weeks of moving in the bath cracked which we reported immediately. We did our best to patch the crack to ensure we could continue to shower until it could get repaired. Fast forward one year and the bath was not repaired and mold was growing in the walls. After weeks of back and forth emails with the agent and threats to take them to VCAT, attempts were made to repair the bath with a fiber glass overlay. The bath repair guys refused to do the repairs due to the original bath not be installed with the correct supports. We ended up having to move out for two weeks at our own expense for the bathroom to be be completely replaced, with a fruit basket to say thanks. After the bathroom replacement we continued to experience water leaks and mold outbreaks, so we moved out permanently.

This house is falling apart. Mould in the back bedrooms, growth in the bathroom. Cannot use a dryer in the laundry without opening the entire house. Ceiling is sinking. Fence is falling apart on all sides. Laminate floor not glued properly and lifts everywhere, a dangerous trip hazard. Yards flood at any sign of rain, built on the swamp lands.

Roof leaks but landlord refuses to admit it. Water leaking from lights and insane mould in both bedrooms + bathrooms. Landlord frequently does drive past and will send passive aggressive messages via the agent to mow the lawn when it's 2cm overgrown. Only positive is that the neighbours across the road are absolutely amazing and will help with fleeing this horrific property

The place was essentially a condemned high school portable classroom where (I assume) a harem of cats died and the remains decomposed into the carpet. The smell of dead cats and must was so severe that I felt physically I'll and my eyes burned. The stunning features of black mold on the roof of the bathroom and crop circles of stains littered around the 'property' adds to my suspicions. Also, they advertised a pool which I only assume they took great creative liberties for what can only be described as mud filled puddles.

The landlord did not complete repairs on the property for months (bedroom door fell off its hinges-not fixed for 9 months, bathroom cabinet door fell off its hinges-not fixed for 9 months, oven door not closing-not repaired for over a year and still not repaired at time of lease end and intercom video not functioning-not repaired for 15 months and still not repaired at the time of lease end). All items were reported immediately to the agent and followed up regularly. The agent tried to raise rent before the end of the lease (illegal). They then raised the rent from $330 per week to $550 per week for the lease renewal.

We had to move into this place site unseen. When we arrived we discovered that the floorboards near the kitchen/living room stank of cat piss. The smell had soaked into the floor and was almost impossible to get out. The real estate refused to acknowledge the piss smell and gave us the run around.
The house was quick to mould and felt wet inside when it rained. Which made the piss smell worse.
The yard was also covered in thick alamanda weed and took two days to mow it/maintain it. When we arrived the place was grimy and dusty, but they demanded it be spotless to get our bond back and we had to do extra cleaning.
Mould, dry rot, broken bath, under the house flooded, house moving/structural issues, roof full of holes.

House is in terrible condition; weatherboards, windows/doors, trimmings, ceiling and carpet are all old, filthy and falling apart. 

Fly wire is broken or missing from almost all windows, glass of the windows is stained by a bad tinting job (most likely diy). Very old, damaged and clunky venetian blinds on most windows that struggle to go up and down. The entire blind in one bedroom fell off onto my head when I tried to lower it the day before I moved out.

On move in day there was a broken window that was patched with cardboard and duct tape, the handle fell off the bathroom door, and there was no extractor fan in the empty kitchen vent. We then randomly received an extractor fan on our doorstep with no communication or instructions on how to install it...

Tiny, dated bathroom with poor ventilation, extensive water damage in bathroom cupboards, super weird shower/tub combo and the mirror was supposedly hung for someone who is 7 feet tall. Hard to check your reflection when you can only see the top of your head.

Terrible air circulation due to the layout of the house, it is humid and stuffy constantly and the lack of appropriate window coverings means it gets very hot in summer. There are also barely any power outlets, especially in the kitchen where they are most needed. 

The "bungalow" in the back yard looks like it could fall over with a slight breeze and is also filthy and unfinished inside and out, with an exposed foundation and no steps up to the door. It also has mega-creepy peeling wallpaper and general "murder cabin" vibes. The yard itself is unmanageable and overrun with weeds and includes such amenities as a dilapidated outdoor kitchen, some dead grapevines, a broken concrete bench right across the middle of the garden path and a rusty clothesline full of ancient pegs that crumble if you try to remove them.

The oven is ancient and by the end of our lease was completely non-functional. When we were asked to renew our lease we requested that the oven be fixed and the Landlord retracted the lease offer and kept us on a month-to-month lease instead. He sent a plumber to fix the oven and the plumber refused to service it, saying it was so old and unsafe it simply had to be replaced. The landlord then claimed he couldn't afford to replace the oven and instead decided to purchase a benchtop convection oven with no hot plates. It didn't fit on the tiny amount of counter space the kitchen offered, and besides, there was no outlet to plug it into, so we were forced to do our cooking in the second living area.

The landlord and agent were both terrible at communication and responding to maintenance requests, and the cherry on top of it all was that the Landlord decided to evict us in the middle of the Covid 19 Pandemic, which was made much easier by the fact that he had forced us onto a month-to-month lease earlier. We got to to the point of BEGGING for more time as we were unable to attend any inspections for new properties during the lockdown, but unsurprisingly it fell on deaf ears.

Literally the only upside to the property is the quirky retro 2nd living area which has wood panelling, an orange shag carpeted bar and cool saloon doors (which broke too anyway)
Also the next door neighbour is very nosy and annoying and will knock on your door all the time for the most random things. Don't live here!!

There is mould present in master bedroom and window frames also deteriorated from dampness, upon moving out after a dry clean the master bedroom was so bad you couldn't walk inside it for 3 days from the mould pores being unsettled and in the air it was putrid. Agent also took my bond blaming me for the 'damaged windows' despite the wood just being old and decaying from moisture in the house and breaking apart simply from opening and closing it. Don't recommend putting your health at risk. Besides that it was ok to live in.

The house is fine but the landlord increased our rent from $480 to $590 per week, which I negotiated down to $570 but will still have to move. They're greedy and don't care about putting out a good tenant. It would be great if it stayed vacant for at least a month so they lose money for making me move.

Generally liveable, however clothes line broke during a storm and was never fixed (over a year later we left, still broken). When we left, they tried to claim $650 on the bond cos the lawns weren't done (they were), we left rubbish (cleaning supplies that were there when we moved in, and a stack of roofing tiles that were there when we moved in), tried to claim broken blinds when I'd noted the damage on the entry report, and generally said the place was not clean. The place was of course dirty when we moved in, and we hired people to clean / mow because we weren't able due to timeline and work. Also have photographic evidence that they entered and did repair jobs (including replacing the stove top for some reason) after we'd left but before they'd release the bond. There was an email chain with multiple staff in the end because different people kept messaging me about specific receipts (house clean, carpet clean, lawns) and saying that I did pass inspection only to them say I hadn't, and they refused entry citing COVID restrictions for us to access and see the problems they claimed on the exit report, but we swing by a couple times anyway and found a bunch of food rubbish in the bin that was not ours and could see dirty footprints in in the entry and laundry that was defs not us. Took is a month to get the bond back in full, I prepared a lot and put in a claim through VCAT but they gave in, I think the evidence that they were altering the property was what made them back down

Nice place, issues addressed quickly, estate agents were nice when they came for inspections, landlord even came by himself to say hello and replace the mail box after someone hit it with their car and he was really nice too. I keep saying nice... It was refreshing not having constant battles lol

Property was in good condition on initial inspection and lease signing, with a few issues apparent: side screen door could not be locked and handle was improperly fitted, causing the handle to fall off regularly, and a towel rack would routinely fall off with reasonable towel use. Both issues were brought up with the landlord, the first only being fixed a year later while the second was never addressed.
During our tenancy, we noticed multiple gaps in the kitchen where rats would get in, resulting in an infestation we had to manage on our own for a period of ~3 months; evidence in the home showed that this may have been a prior issue to our tenancy, but we were never advised of this. We also noted damp, water damage and mould in the north-end of the property, advised of broken and leaning fences that were not fixed, and rotting foundations in the shed rendering it unable to use beyond basic storage.
To their credit, Ray White Eltham were very supportive and understanding, advising us that they would not consider the home up to minimum standards following the end of our lease; we were able to get our full bond returned thanks to our property manager, but had they not done so, we had ample evidence to take the landlord to VCAT for violating peaceful enjoyment of the property as well as failure to make repairs in a reasonable timeframe.
I'm not sure if the property has since been re-let by another landlord, but based on trips past the property, I can see the home is inhabited again and I doubt these major issues were addressed before re-letting with another landlord.
House is covered in mold and moisture

Complained about mould and then was evicted using the no grounds eviction. We had provided them with humidity readings in our bedrooms that were consistently over 90% and asked for someone to come out to review the issue. They said they evicted us  because we hadn't immediately let them know about faulty smoke alarms (we notified them 2 days after they stopped working). There was no formal breaching for that (or anything) and excuse only materialised when they were taken to NCAT. 
They also used their and their family's companies to provide quotes to justify taking our entire bond. 
Agent was lovely but completely useless. Basically said that she sided with us but had to side with the landlord. No willingness to call the landlord out on their actions.

We had a non functional oven/stove top for our whole tenancy there, REA sent an electrician to check it while we were not home and apparently it worked fine however we could never use it once and had to cook on a portable camp stove all year long, REA refused to do any further action after the first check. There was also a huge black mold problem, after 3-4 months of letting the agent know about the rapidly growing mold they finally sent someone over. A building structural inspector told us he "wouldn't even pay $10 a week to live here", it was found that we had a giant hole in the roof which after a heavy rain season, the water had leaked through the hole and flooded the inside of the roof. The inspector also found multiple beams of wood deteriorated and far from safe. Still, nothing was done about this until we moved. Never had any functional heater, the main living room had a old split system but the power cable was too short to even reach the nearest power point. From the point that we moved out to the point it was relisted there was no way enough time to fix the major issues that was found by the inspectors. The inspectors told us at the time that they would fully need to reinforce every beam in the house as well as replace the whole roof, i find it unbelievable that they were able to do all that in the short time of us moving to it being relisted. We never received any compensation for any of this

3 stories. Lots of windows.
The house is impossible to cool down on the third floor where the bedrooms are. We lived in the livingroom/kitchen 4 months of the year because of this. Issues with agency too. Actual landlord is great.

Neighbour around corner is a dog groomer lots of barking throughout the day. Neighbours up other end of alleyway love dumping trash all through the Street.

The house itself is actually falling apart. When we moved in, they put up a car pissed stained (and smelled) curtain in the lounge room, the front screen door was not secure, there was piles of rubbish in the garage and the front garden was a HUGE pile of mess.. like literally piles of dirt which we had to clean. Every time we asked for basic essential repairs (one time the front door wouldn't close so anyone could just walk into our house at any time) they would take weeks to respond/organize and the landlord would try to fix it himself. So naturally, nothing was ever really repaired.
Green moss would constantly grow on the concrete. It was freezing in winter and unbearably hot in summer as the whole house had cracks and holes. The split system didn't work and the one tiny heater in the lounge was from the 70s so it only radiated like a meter around it. The floorboards were rotting through and needed replacement. After living in here for a while, once we found a new place the owner had the guts to try ping us for all these repairs out of our bond which never got addressed. Luckily I made a super thorough condition report and they backed off. Don't live here.
Landlord will attempt to steal bond.

black mould present above doors and bathrooms for months, back deck completed rotted during our time here culminating with a tenant falling through onto a pile of bricks (this was not fixed). mouse infestation, many of who died in the heating vents during the summer months. disgusting carpet throughout the house, and peeling lino in the bathroom+kitchen

Black mold
Back door doesn't lock
Missing glass in toilet window
Attempted break in resulted in broken front door, man came to repair and couldn't, said to just deal with it.  
No clothes line (and not allowed to hang your own)
Letter box isn't attached to the fence (falls and sits on the ground)
Carpet is so old it stinks despite professional cleaning 
Holes in the roof with exposed wires hanging out 
Sliding doors on the cupboards don't actually slide
When it rains the water pours inside the house down the walls 
Kitchen is literally falling apart. Most drawers don't open or close again. Chipboard literally crumbing, cannot use the cupboards. 
Gas system so old that if the wind blows too strong the light goes out and it's almost impossible to turn back on. Have to wait until it isn't windy anymore to turn your gas & hot water back on
The lino is about 4 layers deep with random spots missing a few layers
No proper drainage in the laundry 
Tiles in the bathroom lift and move when you walk on them 
Driveway floods when it rains 
Backyard unsealed / unsafe. Ended up in hospital with a screw embedded in my foot due to the condition of the yard
Most curtains don't close / open
In the lounge there's a wall made from mirror squares. Most of them are smashed and a major hazard

I leased this property in 2015 but it looks hasn't been sold and is leased by the same Agent.

The property is a typical sub standard rental that has not been maintained by the owners.

The property was gross when we moved in and had to spend a couple of days cleaning. Usually issues with a litany of broken things that were never fixed.

When we finished the lease and moved out we never received our bond. When we asked for our bond back the owners claimed the entire bond for a series of repairs - all of which were bogus.

We took the owners to VCAT for the return of our bond and sought compensation for a list of issues during our tenancy.  We received our entire bond back and about $700 In compensation from the owner.

The agent accidentally disclosed that the owners claimed the bond from the previous tenants for repairs they were also trying to claim from us (that were never fixed).

It's a cute old cottage but make sure you do a very through condition report and prepare for a fight to get your bond back when you move out.

The place isn't falling apart but there are cracks in the paint the walls, the windows are draughty, mould grows in the bathroom because it's not well ventilated, the landlord took over 10 months to fix a leaking sink and toilet, and then when he did show up on a day he wasn't booked to come, he was aggressive and yelled at me because I questioned why he was here today without tradespeople and not the day we organised. The landlord also owns the massage parlour/brothel right next door, who help themselves to your bins, washing lines and outdoor furniture. They recently started renovations which are really loud and do them often after 10pm. They also often have late night visitors, the entry has recently changed to the back of the shop front, which is right next door to where you live. Customers used to enter from the normal shop front, but this has changed and seems to be a permanent change.

This flat is currently priced at $950 which is outrageous. There is no laundry or space to install a machine. The bathroom has no privacy because a large internal window pane is completely missing. The flat is near lots of restaurants so full of pests which is difficult to manage. Not allowed to secure anything in the courtyard or use it at all. Literally no outdoor space in this flat. Also, the agency managing it are located in the same property so are constantly nosing around and entering the property without permission. One of the agents is completely mental and I had to ask her to leave the property on multiple occasions.

The house was freshly painted when we moved in however there was a large stain apparent under the fresh paint on the master bedroom ceiling, we later discovered this stain was urine from a possum and rat infestation. 
As some time rolled by we discovered the bathroom exhaust fan and downlights throughout the house would stop working intermittently or not at all, this was due to rats in the ceiling pissing everywhere and corroding the wiring.
The entire house eventually stunk like ammonia due to the wildlife pissing in the ceiling and under the house.
The back deck is completely rotten and falling apart beneath our feet, screws protruding and planks of wood randomly giving way due to the screws coming out of the rotten beams.
I reported all of these issues to the "minimum standards" inspector and nothing was heard back about it.
They were picky about long grass and issued a breach and demanded $600 for "gardening" which I paid to shut them up and leave me alone, but no gardening was ever done, we were harassed about long grass until the day we left.
We were also blamed for black mould appearing in the bathroom and given two weeks to "attend to the problem"
My son fell through the rotten back deck and lacerated his leg.
They also threatened to call the police on me over graffiti on the side of the fence.. obviously not done by me.
I have so much more to say about this shitty experience but it sets off my PTSD.
I feel that 1 star is generous for this slum lord.

Everything was fine with the property and my tenancy (despite the fact that they charged $320/week for a tiny studio apartment) until the beginning of this year when they abruptly raised the rent to $450/week. When I told them I felt that that was unreasonable they said they had tenants in the building who were paying that amount and even more. When I moved out, they tried to keep more than half my bond claiming there were damages to the property that were my fault but those “damages” were there when I moved in. The details are too extensive to go into but when I sent them a scathing email basically telling them to respectfully eat sh*t with evidence they filed a VCAT claim (I guess they thought it would scare me into capitulating to their demands). We're waiting for a hearing at this point so I still don't have my bond back six months after moving out. 3/10 experience overall; the location of the property is super convenient and pretty safe but the property is way too small for the rent they charge, and the real estate agent is a [redacted].

The landlord attempted to
1) blame tenants for pre-existing damage to grounds/gardens
2) extort tenants out of bond money
3) cite parts the tenancy act that never existed
4) lied about advice from consumer and business services
5) use an unlicensed real estate agency to attempt to extort tenants with a $800 listing fee
6) attempted to charge for items not included in the lease (broken roller shutters, air conditioning units not included in the lease)
7) get former tenants to pay $1k to stay out of the tribunal pleading common sense (but spelled commen sence in several emails)

Property was actually pretty decent and we would have stayed on but they tried to up the rent by $400 and we left as it was madness. They then couldn't rent it out and it ultimately got leased $100 less than what we paid. Money hungry owners who only care about getting maximum rental income. 
The neighbours told me there is a long history of this, tenant moves in but leaves after the owner tries to raise the rent excessively.

Old and totally not precious, I would happily live here.

However there are issues: 
1. Advertisement online states features that do not exist, among the missing items are a garage and shed.

2. Clearly a roof leak at some point at the front of the house, there is mold showing on the ceiling and clearly water damage all through the corner through to the floor.

3. Ad states "floorboards throughout" which I suppose is true, except for all of the tiled areas, of which all are cracked (kitchen where the floor is quite flexible under the tiles) and any wet areas (2x showers) where grout and tiles are missing and it's clear that there is little to no waterproofing in these spaces.

4. Rear external wall has a hole into the wall space of the sunroom (or is it a bedroom? I think they counted it twice), there is a down pipe with multiple holes held into the hole (lol) with a bracket that is sure to direct all water runoff directly into the wall.

I contacted the agent:

Me: Hi *****, is the rental provider arranging to have the black mould on (sic) the front room and the hole in the rear outer wall fixed before letting the property?
(Photo of mould in corner of ceiling) (Photo of hole in rear external wall)

*****: Yes we can get fixed

Me: Great, would [you] be able to let me know what time frame that might require? Thanks

*****: If we get a suitable app, we can get it done asap

I decided to cease communications at this point because it was clearly becoming circular..

I assume they will get several applications as there were quite a few groups there to look at the place.

Website states that it's been listed for 28 days and that they just reduced the asking price from $540 to $530 per week.

0 maintanence on the property, lift was broken for 8 weeks and as a result trash was not taken out for 3 weeks and the trash room became hazardous with garbage piled up. Security door didn't work so had a homeless guy charging his phone inside the lobby. Poorly constructed home which grew black mould within weeks. Property manager was practically non existent and never responded to emails

We rented from Dec 2019 to Dec 2020. There is no temperature control, it's freezing in the winter and like fire in the summer (the floors burned our feet). The landlords also used the property as their own storage facility and refused to remove large pieces of furniture (despite assurance by the agency at the time of signing the contract that anything we wanted removed would be removed). We had a whole ugly leather lounge suit just taking up space (we have all our own furniture), a dining table and a hutch. Not mention the kitchen cupboards, shed and laundry cupboards were full of stuff belonging to the landlords that they refused to clear out. I acknowledge this may have changed since we left the property, but proceed with caution (the temperature in particular made it impossible to stay in this property).

Mould ridden, rodent infested hell hole. No tenants have lasted longer than 6 months living in that house, and the owner refused to fix any of the issues. Windows that didn't open, black mould rendering one half of house unliveable, advertised as pet friendly but our dog could easily escape and did several times. The gaps in the floorboards were full of rankness, it was advertised as two bathrooms but one was a non functioning outhouse and the other had a shower that trickled at best. It was recently sold - I pray to the rental gods that the new owners don't try to rent this mould bucket out again.

- Car lifts hardly ever work and you will get stuck in there with no idea on when someone is coming to save you 
- Mail gets stolen as there's no concierge and the building gets broken into all the time (actual apartments are broken into and the building hasn't really done anything to rectify this!)
- Syringes can be found outside of the building! 
- Property itself has mould issues (clothes went mouldy and the wall near windows in the bedrooms are moulding + wet after a cold night with mould growing in the condensation) and you cannot keep the house warm with the 1 split system pointing at a wall away from the bedrooms. 
- The amazing view is going to be blocked off by a new residential building that's currently going up and the works continue past noise appropriate hours so you can never sleep. 
- Changed agencies 3 times over not even a 2 year tenancy.
Exploitative landlord. No air conditioning. No proper blinds. Barely working hot water. Landlord lies and attends home as maintenance worker.

Landlord repeatedly ignored requests for basic repairs, removal of a huge banana tree causing structural damage to neighbours houses and hosting an enormous rats nest, lazy homemade repairs such as painting (???) counter tops in the kitchen.  Multiple trees needed removing due to roots causing damage to neighbouring properties and plumbing. Terrible insulation and also insecure (we were robbed because the back door was easily knocked open despite having a lock). Dodgy plumbing, mouldy bathroom, that shitty stove that every rental seems to have, and a serious rodent problem. Every request for repairs was ignored and then we were served with a rent increase after our lease was up. They appear to have painted the house and removed the tree, but if it's the same owner I would not recommend as he is a complete bastard who has screwed over the neighbours many times over the years.

Entire place was totally run down. There were rats because of an unused compost bin the owner refused to remove. The window sills were falling from the windows (meaning huge drafts in the winter. The owner regularly checked in on the place without our prior knowledge (would often walk past and have a look right through the windows, would enter the back gate and move/take things). A piece of art about workers rights and tenants rights were visible from the street and we were forced by the owner to remove it (who shouldn't have seen it in the first place - there were no inspections planned). Owner refused to address mold concerns (evidenced through emails from the real estate agent), tried to take bond for wear and tear that is expected of a house of its age and was very aggressive towards the (queer) partner of a housemate because they stayed overnight semi-regularly, but weren't documented as a tenant (which would've required them to pay like $300)

Great location, great housemates but the great ends there. House was full of holes and the mouse problem was just something we grew to live with. Landlord's "solution" was to offer to drop off traps but this never happened. 
It rained indoors when it rained heavily. Carpet had been eaten by a moth infestation before we moved in and while new carpet was promised, this also never eventuated. They gave one tenant reduced rent for a month as compensation. 
Real estate agency would sometimes follow up on queries as long as you sent several emails.

The property was not electrically sound, the landlord had done a lot of diy plumbing and wiring, none of it good. The shed burnt down 6 months into living there and they left it for nearly two years, making our back yard unusable with no rent reduction during that time. When it was finally rebuilt and inspected, we were given a notice to vacate. The place was disgusting when we moved in and we left it much *much* nicer than we found it, but of course they still tried to keep our bond.

Hopefully kicking off some good reviews out there! The agency have been nothing short of spectacular, always punctual with repairs and the home was in great nick when I moved in. Even when I've been unwell and need a lean on rent, the agency and landlord were happy to oblige to allow me to stay on with them. 
Of course the rent has increased due to ✨ the cost of living crisis ✨ but honestly finding somewhere as decent as this for the price I'm paying is unheard of in Geelong atm. 
10/10 recommend renting with Buxton in Geelong at least.

Omg okay here's the Google folder about the water damage that we shared with the agency. Every time it rained, our carpets filled with water. There's a video in there too. https://photos.app.goo.gl/uiyT4GEuW8ReHUmt8
The Walls were clearly water damaged, and in the afternoon light the wall we shared with our neighbour looked like a paint sampler card from bunnings! Pics of property upon entry here. 

They sent handyman after handyman and quote guy after quote guy to look at the property, but didn't get it fixed. They did however paint the exterior of the building 🙃 in the 18 months we were there, we had 38 people enter to quote or fix. One guy painted the water damaged wall (didn't fix the leak though) and the ceiling (no need for that...). Three different sets of plumbers came to fix holes and leaks in the roof in the first 6 months. All were up there for 2 plus hours. All claimed they solved it. Then, when it rained, we'd hear rain in the internal wall again...

All the units were impacted by a pipe break thay caused water damage, detailed here: https://photos.app.goo.gl/2krsoCm7KArDeK536

To rectify the damage from this all encompassing flood they gutted the bottom two units, and the one where the flood originated, but nothing happened to fix ours other than painted kickboards? 

They did supposedly renovate the property prior to sale when we moved out 12 months ago (September 2022), however when I spoke to the current tenant (to collect mail) she showed me images of the property and it doesn't seem they did anything.

Appaulling treatment from the property mgmt. flooding and no fly screens. We had a rotted windo frame in our ensuit where the temp would get down to 2° that took SIX MONTHS to repair. Obrien's also charge their tenants fee to pay their rent and when I questioned this he said “I don't work for you I work for the landlord” horrible experience with a house that was unliveable.

House was full of mould, land lord REFUSED to fix it. Kept sending her dad to "fix" it. 

It got so bad my son was in hospital on oxygen for 10 days as it exasperated his asthma. 

Roof leaked at multiple points of the house and the roof was sagging in the kitchen near the back door

The back-door wasn't lockable could easily just jiggle it to get it open. 

The backyard was massive but the "grass" was covered in huge cracks and debris. Just random chunks of cement or wires 

Realestate did their best but the owners just don't care.

We kept on top of them for repairs so they upped our rent then the next working day after we accepted they said they were selling. We had just had a baby and couldn't rely on the new owner to let us stay so we have moved. 

The house didn't sell as the owner wanted well over its worth so its sitting vacant.
Untreated black mould present, concentrated around bulkhead around sliding door to balcony. General wall conditions throughout totally filthy.

I rented this property with my mate last year. The property itself - absolutely stunning, FNQ beach living, divine location. The owners? Fucking NIGHTMARE. They gave us a list of house rules which included not being able to use soap in the shower in case it left marks, having to flush the toilet before, during and after doing “our business” and if we left stains on the toilet we would incur a fee of $1200 to replace the entire toilet, their electric car was left plugged in to the garage and they expected us to pay the electricity bill and charge their car. When it was time to vacate, we utilised the cleaning company they recommended with a fee of $1800 for a bond clean. What ensued was a three month fight with Ray White Real Estate Northern Beaches in which the owners disputed our bond return as a bedside table had a small scratch. We agreed to pay the fee to have the table sanded and re painted and they tried to scam us by having all three bedside tables sanded and repainted when only one was damaged. Two months after our exit report they tried to say that some kitchen items eg a pot and spoon were missing even though the exit report did not identify this on leaving. They also tried to say the house wasn't cleaned properly and they wanted $400 for “their time recleaning”. All in all, rich people absolutely scamming and taking advantage. Ray white real estate totally pandered to these rich owners and allowed them to continuously come back at us for “defects” that were never in the exit report. Honestly the worst experience renting I have EVER had and I would 10/10 NEVER recommend anyone rent this home.

This apartment is honestly fantastic, but I do feel tenants should be aware that there are ongoing noise and harassment complaints that have been sitting with strata for over a year from an owner/occupier in a directly adjacent apartment.
