The real estate agent were professional and sympathetic to the situation however there isn't much they could do so this isn't at all a criticism of them - I had to move out because of this issue, multiple tenants before me have also moved out as soon as the lease would allow. I would rather not say more, other than that I wouldn't wish my personal experience upon anyone.
The house structurally unsound, the bath is rotten, the house is full of cock roaches, the landlord is a money hungry person who never fixes anything.
Held together with mould, colder than a tent, holes in the walls you could fit your fist through, toilet that constantly blocks.

No insulation so inside gets colder than outside during winter, and hotter during summer. When the living room heater broke mid-way through lockdown, we were told to buy a new one ourselves.
The hallway grew mushrooms once due to a leak in the roof coming down the walls.
The power short circuits if you run the dishwasher and upstairs heaters at the same time.
The middle “bedroom” (2m x 2m max) had an open hole leading into the roof space and we were told to ignore it. 
Real estate gouged prices and refused to come to an agreement, despite nearby rentals offering better quality for a better price.

Ongoing water leak for 4+ years to the point that the landlord called me at 9pm screaming bloody murder at me because the water was leaking into their downstairs commercial IP (because they were too cheap to get anything more than free quotes for plumbers to say they'd need to rip everything up to find the source of the problem, so the landlord came an just siliconed everything up multiple times and hoped for the best) Landlord then accused us of intentionally causing the damage and told us we couldn't use the bath or shower anymore. 

Had to take the landlord to VCAT because they refused to fix the oven that was broken for a month. We also had to take them to vcat for a stove top that was broken for 3 years. Ongoing mould issues due to the leaks and landlord contacting us to abuse us and showing up unannounced. 

We finally got at least our oven fixed and the mould painted over. 

Then served with a rental increase and not long after a notice to vacate because the “landlord was moving in.”

Nice place, no maintenance, rude landlord and shit agent

Lived here in 2018-2019 and it had a serious mould problem. Literally everything started growing mould. Even weird things like belts or cutlery. Tried a dehumidifier and it was removing 8L of water every 4-6 hours.

Also, side note, had a slight mix-up with a tradie who was coming to fix a different issue, where I asked for an update on when he would attend the property, saying I'd heard nothing. The agency forwarded this to the tradie who thought I was going behind his back to get him in trouble. He rang me, very angry, and made personal threats - particularly concerning when he already had my address. Raised it with the agency, and the agency treated the issue as if I had made the story up and tried to gaslight me into thinking it was all nothing.

Extreme roof leak in the hallway caused rain to stream down the walls when it rains. We had to line towels all throughout the skirting boards for months, and the mould started growing in the ceiling. Real estate agents kept sending in their handyman instead of an actual room plumber. Everytime he came he would inspect the roof, apply some band-aid solution which didn't fix it and the leak continued. One night the leak was so bad it got into the smoke alarm which caused it to go off at 4am for an hour. The ceilings were high so we needed to get on a ladder and poke it with a broom. After 5-6 back and forth visits he finally fixed it and then painted over the mould. Creaky old floorboards and pretty gross lino throughout the rest of the house.

This house isn't a rental anymore, but I lived in it when it was. The landlord owned at least 3 houses on the same street (the one right next door & then another a door down). They knew for nearly 2 months that we were moving in & transferring the lease into our names. There was only 2 months left on the lease, but we had a letter saying they were going to sign another lease once the first one ended. However, a week after we moved in, we were served a notice to vacate at the end of the lease because the landlord's family wanted to move in. We found out they did the same thing to the tenants who lived next door. I tried to challenge the notice in VCAT. During the hearing, the landlord claimed “financial hardship” despite us having evidence that he had just sold a property on the same street for $3M & had the house next door as a rental. When we left, they tried to take a huge portion of our bond to do renovations for their family to move in (they also did this with the rental next door). Raine & Horne never kept the tenants' version of the condition report, so they were comparing the property's condition to super old photos. Despite the carpets being a disaster when the renters moved in, they required us to steam clean the carpets & then didn't believe that we did & required us to send them a receipt. After all of that, I walked by the house a few weeks later & saw that all the carpets had been ripped up anyway. They also tried to charge us for “streaks” on the walls from us cleaning them that you could only see when the sun hit the wall a certain way, & then I saw them repainting anyway. They tried to charge us heaps of money for gardening and green bin removal, & then I saw them rip up the whole front yard & put in all new landscaping on BOTH their properties. Also, the person who did all the repairs was clearly their friend and didn't even have a valid ABN because I looked it up & it was expired. Finally, the landlord would show up randomly, sometimes with his sons. Living in this place caused me so much anxiety - it was one of the worst times of my life.

I lived at this house for about 3 and a half years. I started in the tiny room at the back of the house but after nearly 3 years I changed rooms. When moving a stack of books from the corner of my old room I found the bottom books to be covered in black mould. We told the real estate and they said they would get it sorted for us. It took them 6 months to get someone to even look at it and this man did not seem qualified at all. He had a quick look, sealed some things on the outside of the house and said it was all good. Instead of keeping the moisture out, he sealed the only spot where the water was escaping, causing way more black mould to form. We told the real estate and after 2 and a half months nothing had happened. Our housemate had to move out as he was worried for his health and we couldn't get anyone to move in. After covering his rent for a month we told the real estate we couldn't do this anymore and told them they needed to fix it or we weren't paying full rent. They gave us nothing so we started paying 2/3s rent as only 2/3s of the rooms were inhabitable. The real estate then threatened to take us to tribunal if we were not going to pay full rent so we did some research and found the room had been built without a DA from the council so we were living in there illegally. We informed the real estate of this and told them how upset we were about the whole ideal to which they replied they would sort it out. We had an eviction notice in our mailbox the next day. Ended up going to tribunal, doing a month of research and compiling a whole binder of everything that was wrong with the house. The tribunal lady was horrible to us and said that we couldn't present our side of the story unless we put a claim in against the real estate (the real estate put a claim in against us for tribunal). Being so emotionally exhausted from the whole deal we settled on getting our bond back and calling it quits. Really regretting it now as I think we could have gotten some good money out of it but we needed our bond back at the time to find a new place.
Black Mould in the kitchen, full on. Declared unlovable, told I was overreacting. Kept my bond and first months rent after I vacated.
Stay away if you like to live peacefully and not submit police reports on your back neighbours every week.

Infested with cockroaches. We received a termination notice because the lawn died. The lawn reticulation was controlled by the owner and was broken. They refused to let us control the reticulation. The air conditioners either leaked, tripped the alarm or didn't work at all and they kept sending the same dodgy tradie to not fix them. Wiring was unsafe. Tradespeople visited monthly without our consent. Kitchen window looks directly into the neighbours kitchen window less than a meter away. We would both be at the kitchen sink avoiding eye contact until they got a blind installed. Bath was rusted. Had the place professionally cleaned and didn't get our bond back. Passive aggressive or just plain aggressive.

Electrical faults in the ceiling, hot water system repeatedly tripped, windows unable to be opened. No real effort to repair until notice to vacate was issued. Electrical repairs carried out by landlord, not an electrician, including installation of an electric cooktop. Safety knife blade left in tenants bed after light fitting above was worked on. Slippery indoor tiles on rear outdoor steps, resulting in injury. Only resolved after injury although reported prior on entry condition report

Unsafe conditions, Ray White rents this property with the knowledge that extremely unwell people with aggressive behaviour live in 12/466 Albion street.  That's why the whole building is empty apart from 12/466.  People move in without knowing the danger & then move out again & they will keep your rent for the time you were unable to live there too (even if you have an IVO & police reports).  The real estate agent claims they didn't know, but later informed me that they were aware the whole time.  The tenent rips potplants out in shared areas, throws rotting food all over the walls, smashes windows, leaves drug paraphenalia in hallways & the hallway carpet is rotting as a result.  After this perosn moved out, the next people are apparently demonstrating similar behaviours unfortunately.  Just don't waste your money by moving in there because you will need to move out immediately.

Was a new build. International owner that refused to fix urgent plumbing. Had raw sewage exposed from both toilets, shower, kitchen sink and bath. Had no plumbing for over a week. Went to VCAT and vacated immediately. Was a collapsed sewer main. Copped abuse from the agent who demanded I fixed it. Said it must be nappies in the drain when I had paid for inspections and resorts that proved otherwise. Absolute nightmare. Owner tried to play the "I'm a poor single parent" card. No love, that's me. They had to pay me compensation.

The owner of the property doesn't fix most issues. We had asked the PM whether the walls were asbestos or not when we initially moved in and she told us she didn't think so. My partner ended up getting his asbestos licence done via his work. The whole house is asbestos. There was a leaking faucet in the laundry, which was located outside the only bathroom in the house. The plumber came to fix the leak, broke an asbestos board and left it like that. We had to wait 2 months before anyone came to fix it. The ceiling kept bubbling every time it rained, I took photos and sent to PM, she replied and told me to let her know when it started leaking through and then she would contact the LL. It leaked through and broke my partners laptop. They sent someone out to see what repair needed to be done and the entire roof needed to be replaced. The person who did the inspection called me and said he had been out to the house before for a similar problem, and that he didn't want me to get my hopes up because the LL didn't want to pay to fix it. Also there was mould in the living room and the bathroom, which upon vacating the PM tried to blame us for.

This property has major water issues. Leaking windows and bathroom. Also has noise issues. Can hear everything from upstairs apartment. Building is well kept but it was built in the early 2000s and has bad bones. Internal pipe issues maybe? Stay clear.

Upstairs sewage streamed through our bathroom light fixture into our bathroom.
During a plumbing repair to the upstairs apartment (also owned by our landlord), sewage streamed through our bathroom ceiling (through the light fixture) into the bathroom. The repair/clean up to our apartment was not completed until the following day... Our landlord did most of the general maintenance and anything else took ages to arrange, you'd think raw sewerage coming through a light fitting would be enough of an emergency to send a cleaning person and an electrician but it wasn't and we moved out the next month with an electrician never having visited.

There is a chronic mould problem that the agency refuses to acknowledge. They blame it on you as the tenant and cite ventilation issues. When told you open windows every morning they advise you leave your windows open at night, even in winter. The kitchen Lino is held together with literal sticky tape and the cupboards are so warped with damp they are a joke. The paint job has permanent cockroach shit stains and the windows and doors don't meet the floor or walls, leaving you absolutely freezing and subject to many pests

Dishwasher broke and took months to get fixed, the floor caved in and there was a massive 1m x 1m hole in the floor in the front right hand bedroom. Constant issues with the property and real estate agency took their sweet time fixing any issues we had.

I lived here. The property has no air con. Dero neighbours a couple doors down, and neighbours on bedroom side has DV.. The kitchen bench barely has space for a chopping board and there is no power points in the kitchen so you have to run an extension cord from the cupboard. No kitchen ventilation or bathroom ventilation. Blinds don't all work. Hot water tank doesn't last long enough for a proper shower and the temperature regulator is really temperamental so you have to constantly raise the hot water temperature to keep it warm.
The front door doesn't even have a handle and there is two front doors and one of them the key doesn't even work right. 
BLACK MOLD on bedroom window facing car park.
Took a year to be up to code regarding fire alarms.
Most expensive rental I ever had for the worst place, in and out!

Only lived there for 9 months, brought all of our furniture brand new. 6 months in discovered mould all through the house; doors, walls, roof etc in numerous areas of the house. Also underneath all of the kitchen benches and in wardrobes. Shortly after discovered all of our belongings were becoming mould infested, clothes, tv unit, back of mirrors, mattress, bedding, literally you name it! EVERYTHING. 
Notified real estate ASAP and complained that the aircon stunk,  took a month before any 'resurrections' were considered. Landlord is his own handyman lol, never went through any tradesmen. Said he seen mould in the aircon but apparently “wasn't an issue”. He was very degrading and rude most of the time. 
Informed realestate we were breaking our lease after 8 months and they tried to enforce lease break fee even though the house was uninhabitable - we proved this numerous times and shut them down. 
Towards end of lease twice we had walked into the house which still had all of our belongings to the landlord being inside and admitted he had his own key! 
Realestate were awful, halfway through lease our property manager changed and they never notified us, we had to find out on our own. 
Property manager kept refusing to give us a time for the final inspection and told us that we shouldn't be present because 'normally we don't have tenants attend'. 
Did not get told time for final inspection until the day of, 2 hours prior.

Landlord is awful. Built and owns all four townhouses in the complex. Wants to fix everything himself, but he's older and clearly has lost his wits about him. Reminds me of that grandpa that insists on DIYing everything with the most obscure solutions. Would be cute if he wasn't actually really greedy and rude. And wasn't cute when one bedroom ceiling stated leaking through the light (water and electricity, fab combo!) and when reported as urgent to the agency they said that the landlord responded that there was nothing to worry about. Took him months of DIY fixes that continually didn't work to fix it. By the time it was fixed the leaks had speak to other areas of that same bedroom. Then once finally fixed (wait until I tell you what the fix was) he left the all the very unaesthetic patchwork across the ceiling unpainted. This wasn't a cheap property at the time, and we paid a lot to live in such a nice and big apartment. The leak had been coming from our balcony above, it was a townhouse apartment. After various tries to stop the leak he decided to waterproof over all the floor tiling. So instead of having a lovely balcony that was beautifully styled how it had been to entertain in, our balcony now looked like an empty pool. He waterproofed it with this bright blue rubbery paint that was impossible to clean dirt and dust from so our balcony looked like shit. There were a few other issues throughout the tenancy that I can't recall since it was 5ish years ago but I remember that he was always just as useless at addressing them. And the real estate were terrible at holding him accountable to a higher standard. All other tenants in the block had similar stories of how difficult he's been to deal with. Such a shame because the apartment itself was lovely!

Building rubble left all through garden beds, star pickets left half in the ground in the backyard (3 year old son severely cut his foot) all the walls/door frames/ window frames were warped, garage walls were always completely drenched, severe smell of mould in 3rd bedroom, all the backyard concrete was cracked in heaps of places and then finally the roof cracked in half.

We lived there for 18 months, it was on a slant, did not have adequate water supply, was filled with mould, possums and rats loved the joint, and the front door never locked properly. There is no air conditioning or fans, it is Queensland. If you have any issues they will be ignored by the landlord who has at least 8 investment properties and just doesn't care about your wellbeing in that house.

The house appears pretty standard for it's age and rental price at first, but the crap is in the detail - literally. The house has an extension at the back that looks like some enthusiastic parent put it together like a DIY addition to a cubby house, despite their obvious lack of skill. This extension is where the toilet and laundry is housed, and also where the plumbing issues are manifested. The fear of having your faecal matter regurgitated in the toilet is real. No matter how many times a plumber was called to "investigate", the landlord did not like the diagnosis of needing to do a major overhaul of the plumbing system. It was so comical, the plumber stated they won't bother visiting again if it was to provide the same outcome, as they felt it was just wasting their time even if it was free money for the callout. There was black mould in the ceiling and cupboards that adjoined the laundry. And there was always this lingering smell of death every time we took a shower, used our washing machine or the kitchen sink as well. If it wasn't for the plumbing issue I would've suspected that I was living in a horror movie with a corpse "walled" in somewhere, waiting for me to solve their murder.

4 bedroom 2 storey house. Bathroom leaked into downstairs kitchen causing oven and stove, which was 2 elements and the smallest "barbie" oven ever seen to not work and not be fixed. Tiles falling off in both bathrooms with the downstairs bathroom growing plants out of the walls.
No fly screens on windows. Main oven not working and had been fixed by owner several times. Severe mould from leaking bathroom causing lots of health issues. Power box caught on fire after owner fixed it and numerous plumbing, sewerage issues. All this for $650 week and only 2 bedrooms could be used due to the severity of mould from roof leaking.

Lived here for 2 years. Black.mould in roof space, bathroom and bedroom. Landlord.painted over to rectify. Mould returned within days. Pipes are 50 years.old and split repeatedly. Water bills were over 500 a quarter and landlord refused to fix or reinburse, fusebox was faulty and water entered causing powercuts. Unqualified trades used to repair until agency stepped in. Front of house has subsidance, and has a 2 inch gap between roof evaes and walls. Gaps upto 1 inch at windows allowing cold air in to property. Water leaked from all u bends, and toilet wastes. Repairs took over a month. Gas heater failwd and took 8 months to repair. Repairer found that flue was asbestos and had been tagged to be replaced in 2019. Hadnt been replaced as of 2023. Upon leaving property a professional clean was done, landlord refuaed to accept receipt and stated proerty was damaged and dirty. Agent paid bond and is now claiming it back from him. Multiple times during tenancy land lord would arrive at porperty unannouced and demand access. This only stopped when i called the police to attend.

Moldddd, we lived here for a year and had to get buy two dehumidifiers and run them at our own cost. The mold was shockingg, it ruined all my housemates clothes and shoes and looked like a bloody murder scene. We spoke to the previous tenants who said they had the same issue though we were never told! The floorboards downstairs had many places where they would just raise from the ground, like it was so dodgy.

Agency was fine, responded to all my requests for repairs in a timely manner. However, the biggest problem could not be fixed while I was there - the mouldy carpet. The carpet was truly disgusting and I had to keep the front door open all day (fly screen closed and locked, not the safest area) just so that the flat wouldn't completely stink.
Also, there was peeling paint in every room and if you have a washing machine in the bathroom there is not enough room for your legs to sit straight on the toilet.

Our issue wasn't with the real estate agent. Our issue was with the Landlord who lives BEHIND the property and regularly stuck her head over the fence to inspect what we were doing. She regularly threw hectic parties that went until 6am on a TUESDAY!! night. The gardens were disgusting and badly kept and they expected us to replenish the woodchips - that did not exist when we moved in - and would've cost us over $1k to replace. The house had 3 air con units from the stone age that barely worked and used so much energy - they were extremely bad for the environment. The house also had major cracks on all the walls, a hole in the garage ceiling so possums/rats/cats were constantly getting into the roof to fight or mate. The front door was falling apart. The back studio was disgusting. The shower was constantly blocking up and filling whilst we were using it because the landlord wouldn't get a plumber out, until eventually we complained enough that they finally sent someone over. The walkway from the back of the house to the studio constantly leaked whenever it would rain and the flooring outside was so slippery - someone could've fallen and hit their head. Would not recommend anyone live here if they value their privacy & want somewhere actually nice to live.

Property itself was decent except for roach infestation which had been covered up I guess when I inspected. I'd been blamed for a bunch of stuff by the agency when asking for repairs etc, so I didn't report it in case they made me pay for fumigation. I'm obsessively clean and never leave food out so I know it wasn't me. They also blamed me for stealing the rod in the closet when I left which I did not do. Insanely strict about inspections too. If there was even a tiny smudge on the shower glass I'd get notified about it. Once they opened the doors of the closet to check how tidy my clothes were. The owner came over once to fix the plumbing because there was a leak and he did a terrible job. Also they raised the rent literally the day the covid rent freeze ended.

Worst real estate I have ever experienced in my 15 years of renting. Unit is falling to pieces with unprofessional, cheap and quick fix repairs. Fence has fallen down with no intention to repair. I was told the place was being touched up and freshly painted before move in but on move in day nothing was done and the condition of the property was much worse once viewed unoccupied. Landlord owns multiple properties and seems to be a slumlord. Belligerent and mean spirited landlords seem to be a match for the agency with their agents lying on multiple occasions and ignoring urgent ammenities repairs/ talking to me like I was dirt under their shoes for asking. Property doesn't pass rental standard checklist with multiple violations. The escalations process within Ray White is basically just a way for them to check if you can take them for monetary damages with no real offer of assistance. Their national customer service representative “Angus” didn't even address my concern and instead tried to milk me for information that would indicate if i could make them legally liable or not. Felt like I was dealing with the Mafia.

Worst real estate I have ever experienced in my 15 years of renting. Unit is falling to pieces with unprofessional, cheap and quick fix repairs. Fence has fallen down with no intention to repair. I was told the place was being touched up and freshly painted before move in but on move in day nothing was done and the condition of the property was much worse once viewed unoccupied. Landlord owns multiple properties and seems to be a slumlord. Belligerent and mean spirited landlords seem to be a match for the agency with their agents lying on multiple occasions and ignoring urgent ammenities repairs/ talking to me like I was dirt under their shoes for asking. Their national customer service representative “Angus” didn't even address my concern and instead tried to milk me for information that would indicate if i could make them legally liable or not. Felt like I was dealing with the Mafia.

Full of mold, backyard was sinking in due to improperly filled pool. Ceilings collapsed. People got sick due to mold, REA refused to take action until compelled by VCAT order.

The bathrooms are full of mold, the laundry ceiling was spotted black with it, the stairs were broken, the heating didn't work for all of winter, the power went out multiple times, there was a gas leak that went unrepaired for over a month.

The landlord claimed they didn't have enough money to fix it.

House made my whole family sick. It has a severe fungal infection. Stinks every time you use a shower or it rains. Significant hidden mould, (only some is visable, look carefully!) Possible (Defintely) water damaged electrical wiring. Super dodgy agency gives zero fks, managed to sign up some poor new tenants a couple days before the new QLD minimum housing standards took place.
My roof fell in and steps collapsed.
No repairs - No heating - abhorrent rental fees . No repairs in 25 years or more - slumlords

Discovered the communal laundry (of 4 apartments) was all being charged to one apartment, which was ours. We told the realestate straightaway and the promised to 'investigate'. Nothing happened for months even when we called, emailed and texted the real estate daily. After 6 months we were charged an obscenely high power bill as the communal washing and drying machine was used continually through this time. We re-approached the agency asking for some small reimbursement as it seemed outrageous that we should be paying for the complexes laundry facilities. The real estate claimed the landlord denied any problem with the laundry, even though we had an electrician confirm the wiring was directly into our apartment. As we were going no where with the real estate we decided to take the landlord to the Rental Tribunal to be reimbursed for a portion of the power bill and to force her to repair the laundry wiring (as we had been incessantly asking for 6 months). Long story short the landlord sent one of the real estate agents (poor little 18 year old chick) to the tribunal hearing and we somehow lost on a loophole. The landlord argued that she 'didn't know' about the electrical fault before we received the bill so shouldn't be liable to pay. It worked for her. The judge, however, gave us a rental credit and ordered the landlord IMMEDIATELY fix the laundry outlets. Small win i guess? However months passed and the landlord made absolutely no movement towards repairing the laundry outlets. We knew we were STILL PAYING for the communal laundry and threatened to return to tribunal. We then received an email of eviction :-) We had three months to vacate the property. After moving out we got in contact with the new tenants of 2/50 Corunna Rd and told them our situation and we found out that the laundry STILL. HADN'T. BEEN. FIXED. After 1 1/12 of us living there and the new tenants moving in. I'm not sure what they are doing about it but the whole situation was just wild. We felt robbed and abused by the real estate and the evil little landlord. DO NOT MOVE INTO THIS HOUSE OR DEAL WITH THIS REAL ESTATE. Evil. Evil. Evil.

Gaps in the external walls leading to plants growing inside the house 
No heating or cooling
Mould
Moult carpets (we pulled up and then got in trouble for) 
Cracked tiles
Dark as all hell
Garden that required to be maintained by tenants but no green bin and landlord refused to get one 
Dodgy electricals, people got a shocked more than once 


At least it was cheap

Didn't have working electricity sockets, they were hanging out of the wall. Lounge room had one working socket. Gas leak that took weeks to get looked at. Didnt have a back door (only a screen door that didn't lock) and took 6 months to get one. Lots of gaps in windows/floors. Broken heater in lounge, would not provide us a report of the last carbon monoxide test. Constantly had little bugs and worms coming inside. Lots of broken tiles and cupboards in bathroom/kitchen. Broken cupboard built in to bedroom. Yard completely overgrown and filled with hard rubbish, which we were told to clean and maintain. Little room out the back that is not fit for living but they use that to advertise an extra bedroom. Lived here 2018 - 2020.

1. Lies from real estate. Before agreeing to renting the property we were told by Belle Property, Coorparoo, that there was a man who lives in the lower portion of the house (a converted garage). We were told he was a 'friend' of the landlord that is fly-in-fly-out and only resides there one week of the month. We were reluctant to rent the house upon hearing about this man living there, but agreed after being assured from the real estate that he is barely ever home. A few weeks into moving in we discover that it is the landlord that lives under our house and that he has no job and very rarely leaves the house. We contact the real estate to ask why they didn't tell us, and they say they didn't know it was him (I suspect they are lying). 

 2. Water Damage. The ceilings appeared to be very water damaged, but we were told they were just stained from a previous leak that had been since repaired. Further into the tenancy we notice the ceilings are leaking, getting more and more water damaged and sagging in a pretty alarming way. We report this and nothing is done. The real estate let me know the landlord is refusing to send people to fix the issue because he will be putting a tarp on the roof. At one point the SES arrived at the house (perhaps due to an after hours maintainer request we put through) and they told us not to enter the lounge room as the ceiling is unsafe.  Eventually the ceiling collapsed in one of the rooms - which did not get fixed for a significant amount of time. All requests for rent reduction were denied. When I contacted the RTA I was informed that there was no legal obligation for the landlord to fix anything, but we had the right to break lease and leave. 
 
3. Threat of eviction. After the ceiling issue, I received a private sms from the landlord stating we would need to move out and he is giving us the official advance notice. The official reason was that he wanted to repair the house. A week later when we ran into each other he verbally told me he wanted us to leave because 'he felt we went behind his back to have repairs done'. I explained that we didn't and he said sorry and said we could stay. 

4. Possum and rat infestation. Throughout the tenancy there were rats and possums living in the roof and walls. A year into our tenancy a possum had made a hole in the wall through which we could see the possum sleeping in there during the day. There was a spot on the ceiling that was clearly being used as a toilet for the possum. This spot was above where a person was sleeping. Eventually a possum pissed through the ceiling onto that persons pillow. This person obviously couldn't sleep/be in that room so they moved into the lounge room. All requests for a rent reduction were denied and a month later at the end of lease we were offered a lease renewal with a $70 rent increase. We left at this point. 

When we were moving out the landlord was painting over the water damage on the ceiling and walls.

I lived at a the property for 10 years, the agency refused to ever repair anything and when I was relocated for the sky rail being built they rented out the property from under me and forced an evection.

Never had rubbish bins despite multiple requests
Bathroom was rotten and leaked into the second bedroom causing mould to creep up the wall
Toilet rocked back and forth every time you used it
Kitchen bench was covered in green duct tape to stop water spills between the stove and sink and into the cupboard below the sink
Lights flickered after you turned them off and using the kettle would blow a fuse 
The pavers on the back deck were all cracked and loose
A window in the second bedroom has no glass, just a wooden board over it, still to this day I can see it's never been replaced
Two gas bottles fitted right beside the second bedroom window that leaked
Electricity lines running from a pole onto the property were underneath trees and too low according to the electrician who came to visit
Entire yard turned into a swamp for days after rain
Crumbling walls that are asbestos
The owner has had this property for years, he showed up (with my permission) drunk and after seeing that I had removed the last 30 years of rubbish from the yard said “good job” and promptly went back to the real estate to raise the rent by $20. I lived there about 2019, paid $300 and after the landlords visit paid $310 until the floods happened. The landlord did the bare minimum to the property after having flood water through it and rented it back out for $430. The new tenants tell me that they still have no bins and despite replacing the carpets and a little bit of the bathroom the place is still rotting.

Backyard is huge but full of cat head prickles so unusable. Ducted cooling doesn't work without using hundreds of dollars of water and the split system they installed to take its place only cools the one room it's in. The carpet is easily 50 years old and impossible to clean even professionally. The neighbours are spiteful, particularly one who reported noise that didn't even come from the property but from a different neighbours house and got mad at the sound from puppies playing in the yard.

This apartment is the absolute pits. As a start, the hot water runs out in 2.5 minutes. There is no heating or cooling. The walls are so thin I could hear my neighbours do EVERYTHING no matter what room they were in at their apartment. Most significantly there is a VERY angry man that lives below who, because of the sound travel, made my life hell. When I told the real estate agents that I was being harassed and had to move out, they refused to do anything to help me. In the end I had to sleep on my friend's couch and then break my lease to end the harassment. Don't live here cuties xx
Poor insulation. Some mould issues. Expensive to heat and cool. Ineffective range hood and bathroom fan. Rent has just increased, but with no maintenance or improvements for the past year.

I recently moved out of a unit in Brisbane (last week)I was paying $330 a week and they were going to raise the rent to $350, however I decided to move out as they refused to do anything about the black mould in the ceiling. There's tree roots growing through the pipes so every few months the toilet blocks up and either floods the house or the garage downstairs. It also took them a year to replace my broken oven. It's advertised as a 3 bedroom but 1 of those 'bedrooms' is essentially an enclosed balcony with a cupboard. It's also like 10 degrees inside in winter and 35+ degrees in summer. They advertised it for $400, had the first inspection on Saturday and it's already been leased
Mould in every room, several maintenance issues reported and never resolved (e.g. broken washing line)

Was mould in the property when we moved in which we mentioned in the condition report. We asked them on multiple occasions to do something about the mould. Firstly they completely ignored that we had complained about the mould and instead listed the issue on TAPI as a roofing issue, and proceeded to get multiple inspectors out to review the roof BUT did nothing the mould and none of the inspectors knew anything about the mould either (in total they had about four inspectors come out about the roof, but nothing was ever done). We went back to them eventually and said that the roof wasn't the problem we raised, the problem was the mould. Finally we were told that someone was coming to inspect the mould. Again they got about four/five inspectors out to view the mould. At least on one occasion when we asked the inspector directly, we were told unequivocally that it is mould and something needed to be done about it. But according to Fletcher's they were told that it wasn't mould and the property was safe to live in. (Not sure if it was by the same inspector or not). They were going to clean it up anyway (suspicious for mould that isn't there) but they would get a quote, sit on it for ages with its status as "waiting on owner approval" and then they would decide to get another quote. After the final inspection from a mould company, we asked what was taking so long with getting the quote approved by the owner and was told they weren't able to get in context with them because they were on a holiday in Europe. Eventually we decided to move out citing the mould as the reason which means we could move out right away. Fletcher's came back and asked for us to stay one more month so that we could keep things amicable. They also continued to deny any wrongdoing. In the finally month we also got a notification on TAPI that they wanted to  renovate the kitchen and so where getting someone out to issue a quote for the renovation. I firmly told them I wasn't taking time out of my work day to assist with this and that they could arrange for this person to come out once we had left. Btw there were other issues with the house such as lights not working, windows not opening, AND the heating ducts weren't connected properly. This was my first rental experience and the fact that I know most people are putting up with worse in this current rental market has made me move back in with my parents. Not a decision I wanted to make.

The ceiling and walls are full of mould. The roof was left with tiles missing and torrential rain filled the roof cavity for 3+ years. Was only 'fixed' 10 months into our year long lease and then we received a notice to vacate.

So many issues it wasn't funny. 
Spider infestation throughout the entire house and yard. “Handmade” water tanks in backyard that overflowed and flooded the back yard anytime it rained. “Handmade” and illegal (definitely not council approved sunroom extension to the main house that festered rats and mice from when the previous owners were cooking in there. The sunroom also flooded from the botched job the did where the gutter met the roof. The whole room was unusable. The dishwasher provided was from the 90's and didn't work and was full of rust. Got replaced with what was supposed to be a brand new one (that we had to collect from the neighbour and install ourselves) but it was second hand and that never worked either. We never got a dishwasher after that. The sunroom/house foundations were moving and we could tell by grout popping out of tiles and doors getting jammed and then loose again over time. Loungeroom fan stopped working at one point in the middle of summer and it never got fixed. The single aircon in the house stopped working before Christmas and it took them weeks to repair leaving my family (inc 2 year old son) extremely distressed with the high heat we had over summer. Mould in the bathroom that never got attended to. Landlord rocked up a few times on their own which was of course a breach of privacy. Window fly screens kept falling out. Wind up windows were painted sealed so majority of then we couldn't open. When we moved in the toilet was leaking. Bath faucet was broken and super sharp. Shower and bath also leaked the whole tenancy. The house didn't come with a pantry also which we over looked and had to get a portable cupboard to put food in. Curtains were mouldy and falling apart from old age. One bedroom didn't have a window covering which we replaced with a blind ourselves. House didn't come with NBN when we moved in. Had to do it ourselves. A few garden beds in the front and back were CONSTANTLY coming up with thousands of weeds. It was terrible to upkeep. 

The real estate who we dealt with also… a whole other story that I've written in the agent file. It was a terrible experience.

Owner.. He evicted out neighbor on no grounds and made him pay for the whole renovation of the place. He left us without a stove and oven appliance for 6 months without compensating because we already pay “cheap rent”. The asbestos fence is falling and we are in a heavy traffic street. And he claimed that the stove was not replaced because we didn't let the appliances company in which is a big fat lie as we were calling them every day asking when it would be changed.

The agent's shop was below us and we shared the back courtyard space. He would open the door to the back and loudly play shitty tv all day everyday. He also tried to get on our wifi and refused to give us a mailbox or rental reduction when we both lost our jobs due to COVID.
Mould. Roof Leaks. Water In The Walls. Structual Damage. REA and LL did not care about fixing for my whole lease even with me pregnant and having a newborn.

Rising damp, skirting boards falling off, paint falling off thebroof and walls. Stove barely works, shower leaks, sink leaks. You can constantly hear trains blaring their horns. Only real saving grace is it's proximity to public transport.

This property is so stunning but very expensive. Agent is nice and reasonable, albeit sometimes unresponsive and slow to action things. We had a few small issues needing repair (windows not opening, wardrobe collapsed) that the agent dragged their feet on a little but with some persistence and probing ended up fixing. Overall a beautiful place to live, we are very lucky.

Landlord was a total tight arse- cheap diy fixes everywhere. Real estate was actually lovely and professional. Sewage was most likely illegal, leaked in front yard and wouldn't fix the cracked pipe, which resulted in horrendous smell and black fly infestation coming out of all drains. Gaps in floor/door so slugs crawled into the kitchen most nights, mould throughout house, put rent up $100/wk for nothing. Place is a DUMP.
Dilapidated house,  falling apart, mold issue, pests in roof. Shit agency.

We paid for the professional cleaners they had recommended for the end of lease clean. 5 issues were noted and we were asked to return. We disputed the 5 issues as they were either listed in the original condition report or were the responsibility of the recommended cleaners. Agent dropped 3 issues but insisted we return to the house only to dust cobwebs and prune front bushes. We had ended our lease 1.5 weeks prior and given our keys back 2 weeks prior. Agent threatened that they would contact RTBA to hold our bond release if we did not cancel the release ourselves and return to dust/prune. The professional cleaners had cleaned the house to a better condition than we had originally received it. We lived in the property for less than 2 months before heavy rain revealed a massive internal roof leak in living room - multiple trades were unable to fix this leak for the 10 months left on the lease. The house had one split system in the same living area as the roof leak. We could not turn on the split system for heating because it would smell of animal urine. The house was poorly insulated with cracks in all windows and all mesh fly-screens were ripped and not fixed during our tenancy, despite our request. Bathroom fan was not working efficiently which led to mould. House had mould in at least 3 rooms. House had clearly been repainted to conceal mould repeatedly, as legal responsibility of rental providers to disclose mould had not passed until after we signed the lease. The mould was inspected by a professional within 3 weeks of us moving out and the roof leak was not resolved - we expect the roof of the house needed to be replaced. We left property after paying $470 a week on a 12 month lease. The property was then advertised for $700 a week - eventually leased for $550 a week within 4-6 weeks. The agency falsely advertised a dishwasher and used an old photo of an existing heating system that had been removed.

Gutters are never cleaned regularly leading to water overflowing whenever it rains heavily. Bathroom windows leak during heavy rain which has made the the bathroom cabinet bulge inside, there was also some mould on the bathroom ceiling, which also resulted in a hole in the ceiling. floors bounce when you walk and floorboards are starting to rot. Almost every wall in the house moves/flaps if you push on it lightly. Windowsills are all ancient and rotting. The gas heater has never worked. There are signs of water damage/mould appearing in the main master bedroom. There's a old toilet room outside which wasn't on the condition report, it has no toilet seat and leaks water everywhere when you flush it. On the back patio all the tiles are coming up and the screen door is ancient and falling apart. A lot of the doors have doorknobs that feel like they're about to fall off and the doors don't stay shut for both bedrooms. The visible mould in the house is probably just the tip of the iceberg really.

Everything was moudly - cupboards, pantry, walls, ceiling. The wall behind the shower (to the hallway) was collapsing due to mould. When I left, everything I owned smelled. Some of my clothes were ruined from being stored in the wardrobe. I had moisture absorber containers, a dehumidifier, and had windows open all year round. When I complained about it every inspection, I was either ignored, or given clove oil to spray. I finally moved out and learned I had developed asthma as a result of living there. It was listed for rental just a couple weeks later, with nothing fixed.

I inspected this rental last year with my partner. We left in complete disbelief. The bathroom was the worst offender, the bathtub plumbing was completely exposed and leakage had been delegated to a removable ice cream tub, which sat on the tiles , at the end of about a metres worth of crudely put together PVC pipe. These strange “fixes” were found all over the property. This was the first major red flag. While superficial, perhaps the worst element of the rental was what my partner and I like to call “ fish in the walls”. Somebody had taken it upon themselves to make a Perspex feature wall for their shower. It attempted to emulate a beach scene, including real sand, seaweed, some netting (which was realistically part of a plastic fruit bag), and three taxidermy specimens— two partially dehydrated, starfish, and one angelfish. I hope it was an angelfish in the afterlife because its body was encased in one of the circles of hell. Yes, instead of fixing the glaring issues in the bathroom, of which there were several, the homeowner decided to put in a transparent sarcophagus for what may once have been a pet fish. It is now condemned for all eternity, to watch unfortunate renters shower. It was so disturbing that I forgot to take a photo, which I deeply regret. 

Inside the shower, the soap dish had been ripped clean off the wall, and the hole was patched up by duct tape. I could see mould along with the rim of the tape. I think that rentals are mouldy because landlords are mostly boomers who are mouldy and rotting and will thankfully be dead soon.

Moving onto the bedrooms, the inbuilt cupboards were made from unsealed chipboard, evidenced by several of the shelves being extremely warped by liquid. It was so noticeable that I found myself questioning what kind of liquid would end up in a cupboard and then decided not to answer that question for myself.
Another thing that I noticed was that there were a couple of ancient air conditioning units that were not functional and still installed into the walls. There were also several new lighting fixtures, one of which was installed so low in the ceiling fan at touch, the top of my partner's head. He is over 6 foot tall plant. The lighting fixture was a candelabra and it would not take much for it to fall on top of someone's head , given how poorly it had been installed. The flooring was an issue, and some of the rooms there was carpet which smelled musty and moldy. This was one of the primary reasons we turned down the property to rent.

Towards the back of the property, the dense foliage had not been cut back from the balcony, making it an actual fire risk. I am talking about large fronds of the trees touching the roof and the side of the balcony. This would also invite spiders and snakes into the house. We knew it backed onto bushland , which is fine. What we didn't expect is that it was flush against the back of the house. This may have been changed since inspecting the property in this state means that they would have expected the tenant to clean it up.

The rest of the house was a blur to me that what I do remember, is that the design was extremely strange. The bulk of the space was a large, poorly lit garage kitted out with tools and a workbench. This was apparently not part of the lease, but your car could be parked in the garage. This was a huge red flag for me. I don't want to meet the parasite that is taking most of my paycheck for his own personal gain,  let alone have him rummaging around in the shed with tools that could kill me.

The design of the house is extremely strange, and the vibes were not it.

Despite the horrors that we witnessed, it is far from the worst rental I have ever lived in.

Bathroom floor had collapsed along with holes in walls and broken tiles.
Took 6 months to resolve then tried to back date our rent reduction stating the works had been completed when there was still broken things.
The 1st bathroom has no grout in the tiles.
There was a cockroach infestation. There is currently a slug problem.
Roof leaks.
Front fence is falling off
Gutters don't drain properly.
Garden walls are collapsing.
Garden table is rotten and collapsing.
Advertised it as 650pw then went to 700pw just before moving in.
Was Advertised as having Aircon.. no aircon.
I'm sure there is more.

Idk where to start. Started the tenancy with 4 working heaters, ended the tenancy with one Vulcan wall heater in the hallway, none in the living area like laws state. The bathroom was re-grouted over existing dirty grout so every time you used anything in there, you'd end up with grout chips everywhere. The bath was peeling? Like the ceramic coating was lifting, they'd painted over it and rented the house with the bath as a feature despite it being unusable. The lounge room wall leaked so bad that twice the swelling of the foundation of the house caused cracks in the walls, exposing the huge amounts of mold all over the house foundation which eventually grew into the lounge. The back room has mold growing on the roof and walls. The kitchen has a gaping hole between the floor and wall where the fridge goes, they'd patched it with some electrical tape. Weeds started growing in through the heater in the back room after it was disconnected. They didn't arrange the gas inspection until 6 months into the tenancy where we learned we'd been using a heater that was leaking carbon monoxide. There's a three inch gap under the front door and no insulation so the house is a fridge in winter, especially with almost no heating options. The drains were so clogged when we moved in that sewerage was spilling out into the backyard which took days to be fixed. There a rat sized hole chewed through the asbestos in the wardrobe in the back room. All of the fixings are older than my parents and barely worked (except those in the kitchen). Half the windows don't open due to being rusted shut. There's lead paint peeling everywhere. There's mold in both bathrooms. The shed is unusable despite being advertised with the property. And after I moved out they upped the asking price $50pw before undertaking any works on the property. Oh and twice I had debt collectors there looking for the owner for not paying their council rates.

The landlord showed up with no notice to “repair” the issues that needed to be fixed. Let himself in and used one of my kitchen knives to stab into the gas stove to try and get the elements to work. The garage door didn't close. There was a hole in the roof which was patched with a frantelle water bottle and superglue. The who gas heaters were finally declared unsafe and disconnected to the realestate provided two Kmart heaters as a temporary solution. We ended up leaving the house after only 3 months and when the house was re advertised it was described as having “electric heating throughout”… the real estate also sent us an email with all of the personal details of the couple who moved in after us.

Mould infested, all repairs done cheaply and badly with handyman and not trade specialist, kitchen cabinets rotting, bloated and rusted; falling apart, pipes scream, upstairs extension made of baseboard and bathroom not sealed which has caused the bathroom floor to rot away to the foundation, and the timber support beams to be soaked, was given a small rent reduction after 6 weeks of trades coming by the house for “quotes”, then locked out of the bathroom 2 days after on a Friday then evicted on no grounds the following Monday. Front wooden gate also rotting and swells with rain causing the lock to not work, was stuck outside in the middle of La Nina rains trying to turn the key so hard my hands bled, when i told real estate about this and sent photos of my bloody hands, real estate asked if i was turning the key correctly in the lock i used multiple times a day for 3 years. Real estate also send around trades and show up without proper notice. Windows have all been given the landlord special which means they slam shut, nearly lost many fingers and had cats decapitated. When we told RE about this, we were told to not use the windows. I have every photo and email I ever sent to the real estate over 3 years backing up all of these allegations

Lived there for and never had any repairs fixed. Property manager [REDACTED] ignored my emails. Cracks all through the walls. Second bedroom had a substantial water leak everytime it rained so I was paying rent for 2 bedrooms but couldn't even use one without all my furniture getting wet. Told me it was a body corp issue, asked body corp they said it was a landlord issue. Never fixed. Dishwasher broke, property manager told us to go to Woolies and get things to fix it ourselves. Ended up having black mould infest the ceilings and walls and had to move out. Got sick and all my clothes and furniture had mould growing on it.

• Mould developed in the ex hot water system cabinet due to a hidden leak. Leak fixed but mould not treated professionally and grows back
• Solar hot water system is shit, plumbing is shit....there was no hot water for a week when I first moved in and I then got used to there randomly being no water from the kitchen or bathroom taps. You had to wait then try again later after using the washing machine (the one tap that didn't seem affected). Sometimes we couldn't shower when we wanted or needed to. 
• The bricked back area is a nightmare to maintain due to grass growing inbetween the bricks. I had to poison it myself multiple times but it kept growing back
• The locks weren't changed inbetween tenants despite a break-in before I moved in, nor was the cut "security" screen fixed, which contributed to a break and enter during my tenancy, $20k of goods stolen and I was unable to use the garage roller door due to the stolen remote
• the landlord later invoiced me over $600 for ordering a real locksmith on the day of the burglary to replace the locks due to the house keys being stolen, despite my trauma and the loss I had suffered. The landlords later agreed to accept the $1300 security system I purchased in lieu of me paying that BS invoice 
• one of the bedroom ac units obviously hadn't worked in years. Ironically, they made me detail clean it for my bond clean.
• the landlords are slumlords. At the time of my tenancy they owned 5 investment properties. 
• Elders Ipswich were mostly excellent and lovely to deal with. I was grateful to be spared from homelessness. I think the landlords unfairly placed them in an awkward position re the locksmith invoice and shit plumbing (that solahart system needs to be replaced but they won't do it because $$$). They allowed me to break lease due to hardship and let me return to the property to clean again rather than refuse to return my full bond (which I got back, thankyou). That said, the previous tenants had moved out because their rent jumped from $300 to $400 per week. When I had to break lease due to poverty, the rent was $430/week for 3 bedroom, no improvements to the property.
• If the landlords or property manager ever read this...you should rip up the bricks and lay down matting before tiling that back area. Failing that, garden maintenance should be included in the rent. Also, replace that hot water system.

House not built to standard, blocked drains at the back, poor foundation & grading of the property which makes the property unable to manage moisture which led to moisture and then mould surfacing from the ground up, through concrete slab and carpet. We lost everything we owned due to this RE continually blamed us for the mould, even sent us bills for repair. QCAT tribunal determined we were not the cause of the mould or the issues in the propert.. Real estate have done nothing to repair the issues that caused this. Instead they leased the property immediately after we left & upped the rent by almost $100 per week.

1 ancient space heater in the living room kitchen area. The house is a dark frozen ice prison. No aircon for summer. Internal doors don't close, floors are uneven. The mould has been painted over in the rooms but you can smell the damp. Bathroom basin is waterlogged and full of mould. The carpet is 70 years old and threadless, no loft. The hallways walls are waterlogged and the concrete is melting off. Leak behind the wall in the laundry.

We were served a notice to leave immediately having found the presence of asbestos in the large hole in the kitchen floor. Located within the pantry, we were told it could not be reasonably amended and to vacate immediately. Upon vacating, a sign was erected for planned renovations from the owner. 6 months later we drive past and the renovation notification is gone with new occupants and no work having been completed. Was the asbestos real? Is it still there as a threat for the new renters? I'll never know. Pretty shit though.

The property is a bit of a hole but we made it a home. 2 years into our lease and a structural engineer comes to inspect the property. We are advised that the property is not structurally sound and to vacate at the end of our term. A few months later I see the property listed for rent at a price increase under a different agency. I reached out to this agency who advised the property's structural integrity was not recently assessed. I advised that Jellis Craig did have an engineer out and we were told it was not structurally sound. I never heard back. Hoping the place doesn't collapse on the new renters being over charged for a mould infested, structurally unsound home.
Got eviction notice from #28 and told via phone it was going up for sale then re listed at $150 more after a revamp. Tried multiple times to claim money from me for a water damaged kitchen bench

Constant leaking roof into kitchen, bathroom and through back door. Water heard to be flowing through unused and sealed up fireplace. Sent someone out to 'clear the gutters' then Agency ignored all further notices of the same issue

The apartment is *fine* overall, albeit lots of plumbing issues in winter due to tree roots growing in the pipes/“old house” stuff; dealing directly with the plumbers was fine, if still inconvenient; and not just that the plumbing would get blocked, but things like grey water from the apartments above us purging back up into our laundry trough or bathtub, or similar happening with the toilet. On the other hand, Little are absolute cunts through and through. We had no word from Woodards that the landlord was changing agency, just received an email a few days before rent was due saying “your landlord has moved to our agency, you pay us now, here's the banking details”—dodgy as fuck. I have/(had) photo evidence of the not-appalling, but definitely very dusty/grimy state of the place when we moved in, inc barely-functional oven and mouldy caulking (seals around the sink/basin); still the agency (ie not the same agent we moved in with) claimed we wouldn't get bond back after we spent a full week scrubbing the place head to toe despite the state of the apartment when it was in its “lived in” state with us being 10x cleaner than it had been when we moved in. My partner (a tradie) ended up recaulking the sink/basin just so we could get the bond back. Little also have some fucked rules about how you return your keys and just a whole bunch more hoop jumping that I remember being outraged by but I don't recall the details anymore. Little also addressed every single email to the one man's name on the original lease, despite that man having moved out (and been removed from the lease) after a few months of living there and the rest of us had been there for several years. As in literally emails would be sent to the three of us, but only addressed as “Hi [mans name] blah blah blah”, including replying to emails we had sent them. We would remind them he didn't live there anymore and who was the primary contact for our house routinely but it never changed. There was defs more I can't remember now. Lived there from mid 2016 — mid 2019. Not the worst property I've lived in, but Little were defs the worst agents in my experience, to the point that even if a property looked idyllic, when looking for a rental after this one, we didn't even bother inspecting if it was with Little.

In our 8 mths at this property, we had works commence without notice on a retaining wall which caused major damage, flooding, SES involvement, owners and thier friends attending without notice, significant mould causing personal property damage, massive electricity bills where power was spiking at 2am-5am despite everyone being asleep, non working solar, pool area caved in and was unusable.... the list goes on and on. 

On vacate they took over paid rent and tried to have us replaced a non approved verandah which had been eaten by native birds. 

[REDACTED] the owner was an absolute travesty to deal with, and I honestly pity the poor husband and property manager having to deal with her.

*Initially rented direct from landlord, then via agency.

I could stand with my feet flat on the ground and my palm flat on the ceiling almost everywhere in the apartment. The walls are crooked, it has rising damp, the stairs are unsafe, there is a cockroach problem, the windows may not close depending on the humidity and the landlord refuses to fix anything - and then delivers a tent increase. My first rent increase was verbally notified with nothing in writing. When I insisted that it was not valid, he refused to speak to me anymore and started managing the property through a real estate agent, who was actually worse. Attempted to fleece me for several months' rent via NCAT despite me leaving the property in significantly better condition than I found it.

Packed full of black and green mould. Should be condemned. 
Owner doesn't seem to care and 2 tenants have now had the same issue in the house

The house is in pretty great condition, no major issues just some slightly dated carpets. Solid brick property with great heating and cooling. The landlord was really great and allowed me to paint whatever I wanted (returned to neutral upon vacating so you're all welcome for the fresh paint!) 
The landlord also did not raise my rent at all during my 3 year tenancy, I believe they own the property outright with no mortgage and they didn't use interest rates as an excuse to line their own pockets. Really lovely of them! 

My only gripe was with the property manager, she was pretty terrible. The decking at the rear of the house is very rotten and quite dangerous, but getting it repaired just became impossible because the PM never responded to emails and I gave up. I don't think it was the landlord avoiding their responsibility as they were really great with everything else. Terrific owner let down by a terrible real estate agent.

With a view uninterrupted by blockout curtains through the diesel-dust-covered balcony, this two bedroom, sometimes two bathroom apartment (subject to mould) is located in Kingsvillage.

Boasting drains that direct water into the carpet, severely underperforming exhaust fans, and a lift slower to arrive than you've ever thought possible on the city's edge, it is a short walk from shops, parks, and downstairs cafe.

Featuring:
Modern kitchen with stainless steel appliances caked in grease and filled with old crumbs 
Average open plan living looking out to city views and the street light across the road
Bedrooms that only just fit a queen bed (assembled in situ only)
"Laundry"- space for washing machine in kitchen, no sink or dryer space, mould in silicone included


Other features include:
Split-system mould conditioner, unsealed timber kitchen, unsealed stone tiles in bathrooms (prime mushroom growing space!)
Secure undercover car space with temperamental remote system, storage cage, and slow indoor water features (in progress)
Gaslighting available through the agent- report any major issues to find out more! 

Please note: There is a secret address that the utility companies have but you don't, and specific Move in - Move out procedures which we won't tell you about in time to implement them for your move.

Terrible, old property. People from Ryde shops park in designated unit car spots. Infested with bugs and balcony door drops glass every time its opened. The door fell off its hinges once and it was a freezing cold night. Paint job is terrible and flaking off. Mould infested.

When I inspected the property it all looked fine, it was clean and freshly painted. Only when I moved into the property, I discovered the hot water system wasn't working, the stove didn't work, the balcony door doesn't lock and there is no key to the laundry (when I get access to the laundry from next door neighbour, there is no laundry facility there - it was advertised with laundry but on inspection, the agent only told us the laundry is behind the door because they didn't have key to the laundry!) So I spent the first week chasing up real estate agent/contractors to get everything fixed while having to eat outside and shower at work. And everything had been fixed except for the laundry facility, the agent/landlord agreed to put a laundry on but it was a lot of back and forth between contractors, owners corporation and the landlords, multiple times I had to stay at home and wait for the contractors. It was never put on during my 3 months stay there. And the reason I had to move out in the end was, the sewage pipe of the building bursted and flooded the apartment, I asked the real estate agent to clean it up and they told me they will clean it up but either I have to find and pay my own temporary accommodation while they doing the work and move back in when it's done, or I move out permanently. I decided to move out permanently because I'm just tired of dealing with them, and the laundry still wasn't there, the kitchen tap leaks and even the toilet leaks. Please make sure they have fixed everything if you are renting this property.

Worst real estate agency and landlord. They have absolutely no consideration or desire to help their tenants. I was left with a cooker/oven intermittently not working for 54 days. I have been left with one bathroom out of action for 10 weeks and counting, and I was told both repairs would be completed within a couple of weeks of moving in MAX.

During the recent storm, my ceiling began to bow and leak water. I tried getting in touch with my property manager, but at 5:20pm on a Wednesday, she didn't pick up her mobile or respond to my messages until the following morning (When she sent me a text message to call her.. professional, huh). I contacted SES as per the instructions on their website who came and replaced a broken tile and cleared the completely occluded gutters (another regular maintenance issue not completed by the owners).

Due to a blockage, I have wastewater backfilling into the kitchen sinks and laundry. The plumber attended and cleared the blockage and explained he had been here last year for the same thing, but the agency didn't want to proceed with the appropriate repairs, so this blockage will continue to happen.

My downstairs bathroom (the only functioning one in the house) was leaking water into the wall, the tradesmen advised this was a structural concern and could cave in. I was extremely patient with them to get this rectified whilst dealing with damp and mould. When they finally got around to organising the reseal of the bathroom (after 3 different quotes), I was advised I couldn't use the shower for 4 days. This meant I had no means to bathe for 4 days, which Chalk were not concerned about.

I try to get things organised, I take time off of work to be home for tradesmen to come through, but they continuously advise them to quote the repairs and leave, then their quotes are too expensive, and the next tradesmen are organised. This pattern occurs over and over again. I am now in the process of using consumer protection and breach orders as a last-ditch effort to have the work completed. 

This agency is a prime example of agents and landlords taking advantage of the rental crisis and exploiting us for everything while giving little in return. The house I am renting is barely fit for habitation and they are unwilling to uphold their legal obligation. It's so disheartening that they expect tenants to live in these environments but I guarantee they wouldn't themselves.

Do not rent this house or use this company if you value your health, well-being, and sanity. I wouldn't recommend them to my worst enemy.

Landlord was an utter bastard, constantly breaching by sending male trades without notice causing distress to the tenant (who had PTSD from a home break in.) Never fixed the broken lights, massive leak in the roof, wiring hanging from the ceiling, mould everywhere from no ventilation in the bathroom, no OVEN, ceiling full of possums and caving in, fence rotted to bits

Good location and good house amenities. However during my time there we had issues with mould almost every three months, the floors started to buckle due to moisture, and we had bees attack us in our bathroom. 

Side note was that the second bedroom only got direct sunlight for about max 15 min on one or two days a year (major cause for my depression lol)

Never did any of the repairs we requested. Mould everywhere. No fan or ventilation in bathroom. Gutters literally crumbling and falling onto the footpath. Front door doesn't open or close properly when it rains. Plants coming out of brickwork above the front door. Super old energy meter. Didn't replace fire alarms. Tried to put the rent up $200 a week after not doing any repairs or maintenance for 1yr plus. Evicted us when we contested it. Hadn't done the proper bond paperwork to put current names on it even though the previous bond holders had moved out in 2019. Lost paperwork of new housemates multiple times. Unresponsive to 99% or emails. Called after office hours. Very hot and cold phone manner. Generally unprofessional and a bad time all round. 

Immediately started “renovations” after we moved out. Can't tell if it's more than a coat of pink paint though. We moved out in the end May 2023.

Never did any of the repairs we requested. Mould everywhere. No fan or ventilation in bathroom. Gutters literally crumbling and falling onto the footpath. Front door doesn't open or close properly when it rains. Plants coming out of brickwork above the front door. Super old energy meter. Didn't replace fire alarms. Tried to put the rent up $200 a week after not doing any repairs or maintenance for 1yr plus. Evicted us when we contested it. Hadn't done the proper bond paperwork to put current names on it even though the previous bond holders had moved out in 2019. Lost paperwork of new housemates multiple times. Unresponsive to 99% or emails. Called after office hours. Very hot and cold phone manner. Generally unprofessional and a bad time all round. 

Immediately started “renovations” after we moved out. Can't tell if it's more than a coat of pink paint though. We moved out in the end May 2023.

carpet coming up at the corners, 3 broken windows, cracked window sills, kitchen cupboards missing doors and the remaining doors coming off the hinges, broken light fixtures, bathroom FULL of mould which the agency saw no problem with and wasn't going to have fixed before a new tenant moved in.

Old Queenslander with the concrete stilts crumbling (chunks falling out constantly) and sinking. At one point our front doors would no longer close due to the movement/sinking of the house and bedroom doors were being planed by a "handyman" constantly so they would close. Requested multiple times for a building inspector to attend to assess and when they finally sent one out (10-11 months into the 12 month lease) he refused to even use the front steps as they water damaged and severely rotten, just painted over. While house rotting and only being painted over. Property not safe for habitation. Agency was actually lovely to deal with, Landlord seams to be the issue here.

Prior to moving in we agreed to keep some of the furniture. Fridge, TVs, washing machine. Everything else was to be removed. When we arrived after receiving the keys, the house was filled with junk and rubbish everywhere. Agency refused to change our lease start date until after they came through and cleared out everything. We took all the junk downstairs so we could move our things in. They then organised a collection. It filled the carport with the amount of stuff and rubbish left behind. Place was advertised with automatic gate and security system and was discussed during inspection then told us after we moved in they weren't working and weren't going to be fixed. This meant the front gate couldn't be opened from the house and required someone to go down to the gate with a key to open it. Realestate also sent someone to the property to completely decommission the gate and security system meaning the gate could not be closed and needed to be propped open. This was a security risk as the gate should have been able to close to secure the property. They did not send an entry notice when that person was coming to the property, we arrived with the gate closed using cable wires. They tried to take us to Qcat for our bond, however given the state of how we found the property we won. We gave some money as we didn't get the carpets cleaned. The house is old and has not been maintained so everything has a feel of not completely clean. The trees in the property drop a lot of leaves so need to be cleaned often. The realestate was taken over when we left however they kept the same staff.

The property is so worn down it's ridiculous- the light sockets leak when it rains, the heating doesn't work, the windows can't open, the garage shed is falling apart, there are holes in the laundry walls that lead through the brickwork outside (they've tried to hide this with cupboards) and the stumps are shifting so there are sections where the floor has lifted away from the walls and you can see outside. The landlord has 0 interest in fixing any of this, and he and the PM would get mad and reply very rudely any time we tried to follow up on this. The garage shed was full of a hydroponics system that we got rid of when we moved in, and is covered in graffiti messages that they've just blacked out the slurs in. Not to mention the exposed wiring everywhere and the outdated fuse box that trips if more than 2 things are turned on in the kitchen! At the end of the lease they had the audacity to try and keep our bond for 'dirty skirting board's, which was quickly dropped when we tried to fight it. They wouldn't give up though and kept $15 claiming they needed to clean the range hood. 3 years later and we sent the brother in law in to fake inspect it when it was up for rent again last year, absolutely nothing has been changed or fixed.

Apartment first flooded less than 3 weeks after moving in, I discovered it during the night when I slipped over on the tiles and fell in the water on the way to the bathroom. Water had come through the back door of the ground floor apartment, there was already sand bags in place to try and stop it but they didn't work. Flooded again two weeks later, emailed PM again and sent photos, notified her that the water was coming through the back door and also the walls, was told to just put towels down. No flooding for the next 6 months as it was winter so less rainfall during those months in Qld. Flooded a third time so I emailed the PM, she responded saying that the issue would always occur during heavy rain due to the slope of the property and that she suggest I put towels down. A month later I came home from 2 nights away and discovered that the apartment had flooded again, took photos and sent to the PM. She replied asking for more evidence, suggested I might have left the washing machine on to cause flooding, even though I hadn't been home for days. I responded and said this was a known ongoing issue and when I emailed previously she said nothing could be done about it.
